title: AI Distinguished Speaker Series: An Imperative for AI Literacy for All
organization: College of Humanities and Social Sciences (CHSS)
description:
The College of Humanities and Social Sciences is launching the  AI   Distinguished Speaker Series,  a yearlong exploration of how artificial intelligence is reshaping human systems, knowledge, and society, and the role that humanities and social sciences could and should play in framing the questions and guiding the regulation of these systems. Designed to be inclusive and engaging, the series will bring thought leaders to campus who not only explain emerging technologies but also invite students and the wider community into critical conversations about their impact. 
 "An Imperative for AI Literacy for All" with Sri Yeswanth (Yash) Tadimalla, PhD 
 Dr. Tadimalla will present an interdisciplinary approach to understanding AI, its socio-technical implications, and its practical applications for all levels of education. The talk will highlight ways to understand the scope and technical dimensions of AI, learning how to interact with Gen-AI in an informed and responsible way, the socio-technical issues of ethical and responsible AI, and the social and future implications of AI.  Read More 
   
 
 Wednesday, October 8, 10 a.m. - 11:30 a.m. 
 Presentation Hall 
 Register to Attend 
 Students attending this session as part of a course requirement should indicate their course and instructor information as indicated on the registration form.

title: CSAM Science Teaching Program - Program Meeting
description:
The  CSAM Science Teaching Program  holds  biweekly meetings  that are open, welcoming, and inclusive! Any student curious about science teaching is invited to join us. Each meeting highlights a theme related to science education, from classroom strategies to career pathways, and offers students opportunities to connect with mentors, explore internships, and gain real-world experience working with teachers and children. Students are encouraged to  bring a guest  who may also be interested in exploring science teaching. 
 These gatherings help us build a strong  community of support , where students encourage one another, share experiences, and access valuable opportunities such as  scholarships, paid internships, and mentoring  from advanced peers and in-service science teachers. Whether you are just beginning to explore the idea of teaching or already on the path toward certification, these meetings are a place to grow, learn, and belong.

title: Raising Capital for A Small Business: presented by Dr. Len Harac
location: Feliciano School of Business, SBUS Room 140
description:
We are pleased to welcome  Dr. Len Harac, President of Harac Consulting , as our guest speaker for this special event on  how to secure angel investing for your startup . 
 Dr. Harac has been providing strategic and tactical business consulting since 1985 and has served as an advisor to angel investors. He will share insights on what investors look for, how to position your startup for funding, and the steps needed to become “investment ready.” 
 This session will be especially valuable for students interested in entrepreneurship and startups, offering practical advice on pitching, attracting early-stage capital, and avoiding common mistakes. Attendees will also have the chance to ask questions and gain first-hand perspective from an experienced business strategist with decades of expertise in investment readiness. 
 Event Details: 📍  School of Business, Room 140 🗓  Tuesday, October 8th ⏰  2:00–3:30 PM

title: Pop Princess: Evolution of the Pop Genre
description: An exploration of how the pop genre has changed from the 2000s and onwards. Also, a deep-dive into the inevitable and everlasting impact of the female singers within  on American culture. We’ll be talking about famous artists like Taylor Swift, Ariana Grande, Beyonce alongside up-and-coming younger musicians such as Katseye, Billie Eilish, Olivia Rodrigo, and more. Bonus - we’re going to listen to some of Taylor Swift’s  Life of a Showgirl  as the newest example of the genre!

title: JET Program Information Session
organization: College of Humanities and Social Sciences (CHSS)
description:
The Japan Exchange and Teaching (JET) Program offers young professionals the opportunity to work in Japan as Assistant Language Teachers (ALTs) or Coordinators for International Relations (CIRs). Since 1987, More than 70,000 JET Program participants from 75 countries have lived and worked in cities, towns and villages throughout Japan. Join JET and become part of this exclusive network of like-minded international enthusiasts! 
 Come and learn more about the experience, directly from a former JET Program participant! 
 Location:  Conrad Schmitt Hall, Room 125 
 Date:  Wednesday, October 8th 
 Time:  2:00-3:30 p.m. 
 Free Event, all are welcome; Japanese Refreshments

title: NASO General Body Meeting
description: Join us for the Native African Student Organization's General Body Meeting! This is a space where we come together to celebrate and explore the richness of African cultures, while also connecting with other cultures from around the world. At each meeting, we'll engage in lively discussions, learn about Africa’s diverse history, traditions, and current events, and empower each other to understand and embrace our heritage. Whether you're looking to deepen your cultural knowledge, make meaningful connections, or simply have fun with fellow students who share a passion for Africa and global cultures, this is the place to be! Let’s build a supportive community, amplify African voices on campus, and create lasting friendships. All are welcome, come, learn, share, and connect!

title: NJ Center for Indigenous Justice Welcoming Ceremony
organization: College of Humanities and Social Sciences (CHSS)
description:
Join us in welcoming the NJCIJ, a new center on campus dedicated to upholding Indigenous sovereignty, immersing students in holistic educational experiences, and walking in partnership with Tribal communities to re-Indigenize New Jersey. 
   
 The Ceremony will be a celebration of the efforts of all students, staff, faculty, alumni, community members, Indigenous partners, and Tribal leaders who’ve contributed to this significant accomplishment. 
   
 The event will feature reflections from Tribal leaders, students, faculty, and staff. It will also include a performance by the Red Blanket Singers, a drum and dance group from the Nanticoke Tribe. Reception will follow in SBUS Terrace.

title: Information Session- Wednesday, October 8, 2025
description:
The Office of Residence Life is hiring Community Assistants (CA) for the 2026-2027 Academic Year!  
 Applicants are required to attend one of our information sessions.  
 The CA is responsible for the day-to-day interaction and development of the students who reside in the residence halls. CAs live in the halls and supervise a floor or area within the community. CAs take on many roles, such as community builders, role models, peer educators, crisis managers, team players, and administrators. They are student leaders who help our residential students feel acclimated and comfortable on campus. General responsibilities include: maintaining a safe and secure environment for resident students, overnight and weekennd on-call responsibilities, community development, and associated administrative duties.  
   
 To be eligible to apply, you must have a 2.75 or higher semester and cumulative GPA, be in good conduct standing, have at least 50 credits, and be available for all of the student staff training and before and after the semester move-in responsibilities. 
 For more information, visit  our website. 
 If you have any questions, please email ORLjobs@montclair.edu.

title: Threads of Us - Integrative Studio II Student-Led Exhibition
description:
The Department of Art & Design is delighted to announce the Integrative Studio II Student-Led Exhibition for the Fall 2025 semester. This exhibition will feature 3 sections of ISII course:  Threads of Us - Origins,   Pathways , and  New Horizon.  This exhibition will be on view in Finley Gallery from October 07 to November 4, 2025.  The opening reception is Tuesday, Oct. 7 from 2:30-4:30pm.  
   
 The ISII exhibition is the culmination of a six-week journey shared by visual arts majors across three sections of Integrative Studio II. Using the piñata as a point of origin for their investigation, the artists delved deeply into the subject to expand their understanding of its history, materiality, and cultural significance. Building on this initial research, they created artworks across media exploring a range of themes, including construction, deconstruction, regeneration, and transformation. The student-artists collectively organized this public sharing of their work, together they met the challenge of presenting a visual throughline within the shared gallery spaces while still highlighting the unique voices of each class section. 
   
 SECTION 01:   Pathways   led by Professor Jess Blaustein 
 Andy Bermudez, Christian Campoverde, Rose Perez Cruz, Duy-Minh Do, Steven Jackson, Trevor Jennings, Will Kliment, Valerie Luxama, Tasir Plant, Luz Plata, Emmanuella Ponzio, Daniel Portillo, Denilson Raez, Shyeann Rapley, Fabrizio Rufasto, Giacomo Valerin

title: Threads of Us - Integrative Studio II Student-Led Exhibition
description:
The Department of Art & Design is delighted to announce the Integrative Studio II Student-Led Exhibition for the Fall 2025 semester. This exhibition will feature 3 sections of ISII course:  Threads of Us - Origins,   Pathways , and  New Horizon.  This exhibition will be on view in Finley Gallery from October 07 to November 4, 2025.  The opening reception is Tuesday, Oct. 7 from 2:30-4:30pm.  
   
 The ISII exhibition is the culmination of a six-week journey shared by visual arts majors across three sections of Integrative Studio II. Using the piñata as a point of origin for their investigation, the artists delved deeply into the subject to expand their understanding of its history, materiality, and cultural significance. Building on this initial research, they created artworks across media exploring a range of themes, including construction, deconstruction, regeneration, and transformation. The student-artists collectively organized this public sharing of their work, together they met the challenge of presenting a visual throughline within the shared gallery spaces while still highlighting the unique voices of each class section. 
   
 SECTION 01:   Pathways   led by Professor Jess Blaustein 
 Andy Bermudez, Christian Campoverde, Rose Perez Cruz, Duy-Minh Do, Steven Jackson, Trevor Jennings, Will Kliment, Valerie Luxama, Tasir Plant, Luz Plata, Emmanuella Ponzio, Daniel Portillo, Denilson Raez, Shyeann Rapley, Fabrizio Rufasto, Giacomo Valerin 
   
 SECTION 02:  Origins   led by Professor Simone Couto 
 Edwin Acevedo, Mari Ahmed, Chez Amos, Rebecca Atwood, Lloyd Zheng, Veronica Avignone, Sarena Campos, Emily Garces, Keaoh Gonzalez, Katelin Guaman, Aj Malabunga, Jenna Mcdonough, Teiona Mcnair, Angeline Ortiz, Dante Ricci, Javier Salas, Ashly Solorzano 
   
 SECTION 03 :  New Horizons   led by Professor Genevieve Lowe 
 Timothy Andras, Janelsy Caceres, Marisol Coliente-izelo, Catalina Ferraro, Matthew Ferraro, Dylan Forbes, Alexa Grasso, Amanda Lerner, Keita Mcfarlane, Melanie Medina, Jeremiah Molin, Kevin Pena, Rosie Santos, Swetha Sivakumar, Diana Valdes, Beyza Yildiz 
   
 Don’t miss your chance to see the work of our talented Art & Design students!

title: Weekly Food Recovery Initiative
description:
Join our weekly Food Recovery events, where dedicated volunteers and members gather to make a difference in our community. Each week, participants help collect perfectly good leftover food from Gourmet Dining and transport it to Blanton. There, the food is repackaged into individual microwavable containers and stocked in the food pantry, providing meals for those in need throughout the week.  
 To Participate : RSVP to attend the event each week. Meet in Blanton Hall Residence Hall Kitchenette in the Communal Area (Tell them you are working with Food Recovery), Sign in via Event Pass and your set! 
 Requirements: 
 
 Volunteers must be Food Safe Certified to participate. 
 Complete the certification by following the step-by-step instructions provided in this   link . 
 Once certified, email your certification to foodrecoverynetwork@sgamsu.org to confirm your eligibility to participate. 
 
 Your involvement helps reduce food waste and insecurity while supporting individuals in our community who are in need. We look forward to your participation! *Please Note: This event end time is dependent on the amount of food given. You can estimate for max of hour and a half for recoveries.

title: Patriotic Trivia
description:
Think you know your U.S. history, government, and pop culture?  Put your knowledge to the test in our high-energy game of  Patriotic Trivia ! 💥 Join us for a fun and fast-paced showdown where teams will compete in classic Jeopardy style, answering trivia questions that celebrate all things America—from the Constitution and civic milestones to iconic moments and figures that shaped our nation.  Bring your A-game and your appetite—yes, there’s free food, because life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness tastes better on a full stomach. 
 Open to all students, faculty, and staff —bring your love for democracy, and maybe even a little friendly competition. Prizes, bragging rights, and patriotic pride are on the line. Let’s see who really knows their stars and stripes!

title: CALI SCHOOL OF MUSIC: Faculty Cello Recital with Christine Lamprea
description:
Faculty Cello Recital with Christine Lamprea 
 Christine Lamprea  celebrates her fifth year at Cali with a recital featuring two great works for cello, the  Cello Concerto in B Minor  by  Antonin Dvorak , and  Tan Dun 's  Sonata for Cello and Piano  from his musical score from the movie  Crouching Tiger Hidden Dragon . Please join Ms. Lamprea and pianist  Hyungjin Choi  for a recital celebrating some of the best works written for cello.   
 Bio: 
 Hailed a “firebrand” (IncidentLight.com) and noted for her “supreme panache” (The Boston Musical Intelligencer), cellist and Sphinx Medal of Excellence winner Christine Lamprea made her Carnegie Hall debut as soloist in 2013. She has since performed with orchestras such as the Costa Rica National Symphony, Detroit Symphony,  Houston Symphony, New Jersey Symphony, and San Antonio Symphony, among others. In demand as a chamber musician, she has performed with such musicians as Shmuel Ashkenasi, Sarah Chang, Itzhak Perlman, Roger Tapping, and Carol Wincenc. Ms. Lamprea is cello professor at the John J. Cali School of Music at Montclair State University, the Longy School of Music of Bard College and Boston University's College of Fine Arts.

title: Khaṅkhaṇā: The Sound of Dancing Feet | The Nrityagram Dance Ensemble
description:
Nrityagram Dance Ensemble, hailed as one of India’s premier Odissi dance companies, has captured the world’s imagination with its extraordinary artistry and profound commitment to the ancient tradition of Odissi. We're excited to bring their performance  Khaṅkhaṇā  to Montclair State University this fall!  Show your student ID at the PEAK desk in the lobby when you arrive for a surprise gift from PEAK! 
   
 The company’s approach is rooted in the traditional Gurukula system, where students and teachers live in close harmony, absorbing not just dance technique but the very spirit of the Guru. The Ensemble’s performances have been described as “mysterious, eternal, and beautiful” by The New York Times, reflecting their ability to transport audiences to realms of magic, devotion, and ethereal beauty. 
   
 With its dedication to blending the wisdom of the past with the vibrancy of the present, Nrityagram continues to inspire awe around the world. Its performances, both ancient and contemporary, invite audiences to witness the timeless dance of love, union, and spiritual transcendence, embodied through the delicate, powerful movements of Odissi. 
   
 To join us, be sure to pick up your free student ticket from the Alexander Kasser Theatre box office or our mobile box office in the student center lobby, Tuesday - Thursday, 11:30 AM to 2:00 PM from September 30th to October 9th. See you there!

title: Threads of Us - Integrative Studio II Student-Led Exhibition
description:
The Department of Art & Design is delighted to announce the Integrative Studio II Student-Led Exhibition for the Fall 2025 semester. This exhibition will feature 3 sections of ISII course:  Threads of Us - Origins,   Pathways , and  New Horizon.  This exhibition will be on view in Finley Gallery from October 07 to November 4, 2025.  The opening reception is Tuesday, Oct. 7 from 2:30-4:30pm.  
   
 The ISII exhibition is the culmination of a six-week journey shared by visual arts majors across three sections of Integrative Studio II. Using the piñata as a point of origin for their investigation, the artists delved deeply into the subject to expand their understanding of its history, materiality, and cultural significance. Building on this initial research, they created artworks across media exploring a range of themes, including construction, deconstruction, regeneration, and transformation. The student-artists collectively organized this public sharing of their work, together they met the challenge of presenting a visual throughline within the shared gallery spaces while still highlighting the unique voices of each class section. 
   
 SECTION 01:   Pathways   led by Professor Jess Blaustein 
 Andy Bermudez, Christian Campoverde, Rose Perez Cruz, Duy-Minh Do, Steven Jackson, Trevor Jennings, Will Kliment, Valerie Luxama, Tasir Plant, Luz Plata, Emmanuella Ponzio, Daniel Portillo, Denilson Raez, Shyeann Rapley, Fabrizio Rufasto, Giacomo Valerin 
   
 SECTION 02:  Origins   led by Professor Simone Couto 
 Edwin Acevedo, Mari Ahmed, Chez Amos, Rebecca Atwood, Lloyd Zheng, Veronica Avignone, Sarena Campos, Emily Garces, Keaoh Gonzalez, Katelin Guaman, Aj Malabunga, Jenna Mcdonough, Teiona Mcnair, Angeline Ortiz, Dante Ricci, Javier Salas, Ashly Solorzano 
   
 SECTION 03 :  New Horizons   led by Professor Genevieve Lowe 
 Timothy Andras, Janelsy Caceres, Marisol Coliente-izelo, Catalina Ferraro, Matthew Ferraro, Dylan Forbes, Alexa Grasso, Amanda Lerner, Keita Mcfarlane, Melanie Medina, Jeremiah Molin, Kevin Pena, Rosie Santos, Swetha Sivakumar, Diana Valdes, Beyza Yildiz 
   
 Don’t miss your chance to see the work of our talented Art & Design students!

title: CALI SCHOOL OF MUSIC: Viola Masterclass with Molly Carr
description:
The acclaimed violist  Molly Carr —a member of the renowned  Juilliard String Quartet —will present a  Viola Masterclass  from 2:30 to 4:30 PM, followed by an evening  Recital titled "Viola Bouquet"  at 7:00 PM on Friday, October 10, 2025. 
 The  Viola Bouquet  program offers a vibrant exploration of the viola’s expressive range across various musical eras and styles. Florence Price’s  Elfentanz  showcases the instrument’s agility and charm, while Schumann’s  Fantasiestücke  delves into the lyrical soul of the Romantic tradition. Amy Beach’s  Romance , arranged for viola, brings an intimate, melodic tenderness, and York Bowen’s  Sonata in C minor  closes the evening with its sweeping drama and rich harmonic depth. Together, these works highlight the viola’s unique ability to convey both elegance and emotional power—bridging the delicate and the dynamic across a diverse musical landscape. 
 Bio: 
 Violist  Molly Carr  enjoys a diverse musical career as recitalist, chamber musician, educator, and artistic director. The recipient of numerous international awards, including the Primrose International Viola Competition, Chamber Music America, ProMusicis Foundation, and the Davidson Institute, she was honored in 2018 at the United Nations for her work with refugees around the globe through the Novel Voices Refugee Aid Project. Her performances have taken her across North America, Europe, the Middle East, and Asia and been featured in the New York Times, Forbes, and the Wall Street Journal as well as on PBS, CNN, NPR, and BBC World News. Carr is the founding director of the award-winning Project: Music Heals Us, a nonprofit that brings free chamber music performances and interactive programming to marginalized populations with limited ability to access the arts. In addition to serving on the Juilliard Pre-College faculty, she’s also on the faculties of Bard College Conservatory of Music and Musical Arts Madrid.

title: Borders, Bodies, and Belonging: A Justice Workshop with Paola Mendoza
description: This event is a student-centered justice workshop led by renowned author and activist Paola Mendoza. Through storytelling, dialogue, and interactive engagement, the workshop explores themes of migration, identity, and belonging, centering lived experiences and community empowerment. The event will utilize the Student Center Ballrooms for a facilitated group workshop that includes small group activities, brief multimedia presentations, and open discussion. The space will be arranged to support collaborative learning, inclusivity, and accessibility. This event is free and open to all students, staff, and faculty, and is designed to support campus diversity, equity, and inclusion initiatives.

Each cover presents a description of why this book was banned or challenged.

This isn’t just any haunted house… it’s  TWO floors of spine-tingling terror , packed with professional actors, cinematic sets, and horror that comes at you from every angle. You’ll wind your way through dark hallways, creepy rooms, and unexpected scares that will have your whole group jumping.

Whether you’re a horror junkie or just want to test your courage, this trip promises  non-stop thrills  and  free transportation  to make the ride a little less frightening (maybe).

title: CALI SCHOOL OF MUSIC: Faculty Piano Recital with Tatyana Kebuladze
description:
FACULTY  PIANO  RECITAL - All Brahms Program  
 TATYANA KEBULADZE ,  piano with a special guest  WAN-YI PAN,  cello 
 A native of Kyiv, Ukraine, the pianist  Tatyana Kebuladze  has appeared as soloist, accompanist and lecturer throughout the United States and Europe, which include prestigious venues like Carnegie Hall, 92nd Street Y, NJPAC, The DiMenna Center for Classical Music and Kosciuszko Foundation. 
 Ms.Kebuladze holds degrees from Montclair State University and Rutgers University. She has been a member of the piano faculty at Montclair State University since 2004. 
 In addition to her teaching position, Professor Kebuladze is a Program Director at Stokes Music Camp, Artistic Director and owner of Oranta Music Academy, founding member of Montclair Piano Trio and serves on the Board of Directors of the Tcherepnin Society.

title: Threads of Us - Integrative Studio II Student-Led Exhibition
description:
The Department of Art & Design is delighted to announce the Integrative Studio II Student-Led Exhibition for the Fall 2025 semester. This exhibition will feature 3 sections of ISII course:  Threads of Us - Origins,   Pathways , and  New Horizon.  This exhibition will be on view in Finley Gallery from October 07 to November 4, 2025.  The opening reception is Tuesday, Oct. 7 from 2:30-4:30pm.  
   
 The ISII exhibition is the culmination of a six-week journey shared by visual arts majors across three sections of Integrative Studio II. Using the piñata as a point of origin for their investigation, the artists delved deeply into the subject to expand their understanding of its history, materiality, and cultural significance. Building on this initial research, they created artworks across media exploring a range of themes, including construction, deconstruction, regeneration, and transformation. The student-artists collectively organized this public sharing of their work, together they met the challenge of presenting a visual throughline within the shared gallery spaces while still highlighting the unique voices of each class section. 
   
 SECTION 01:   Pathways   led by Professor Jess Blaustein 
 Andy Bermudez, Christian Campoverde, Rose Perez Cruz, Duy-Minh Do, Steven Jackson, Trevor Jennings, Will Kliment, Valerie Luxama, Tasir Plant, Luz Plata, Emmanuella Ponzio, Daniel Portillo, Denilson Raez, Shyeann Rapley, Fabrizio Rufasto, Giacomo Valerin 
   
 SECTION 02:  Origins   led by Professor Simone Couto 
 Edwin Acevedo, Mari Ahmed, Chez Amos, Rebecca Atwood, Lloyd Zheng, Veronica Avignone, Sarena Campos, Emily Garces, Keaoh Gonzalez, Katelin Guaman, Aj Malabunga, Jenna Mcdonough, Teiona Mcnair, Angeline Ortiz, Dante Ricci, Javier Salas, Ashly Solorzano 
   
 SECTION 03 :  New Horizons   led by Professor Genevieve Lowe 
 Timothy Andras, Janelsy Caceres, Marisol Coliente-izelo, Catalina Ferraro, Matthew Ferraro, Dylan Forbes, Alexa Grasso, Amanda Lerner, Keita Mcfarlane, Melanie Medina, Jeremiah Molin, Kevin Pena, Rosie Santos, Swetha Sivakumar, Diana Valdes, Beyza Yildiz 
   
 Don’t miss your chance to see the work of our talented Art & Design students!

title: Art Forum featuring Ellie Krakow
description:
The Department of Art & Design presents the Fall 2025 Art Forum series. Art Forum is a speaker series featuring artists, designers, art historians, curators, and art critics from around the world presenting their work and ideas in an open forum.   
   
 The next speaker in this engaging series is Ellie Krakow, an interdisciplinary artist whose practice spans sculpture, drawing, and photography. Ellie will be discussing her art, process, and share insights into her latest work.   
   
 Ellie Krakow’s latest body of work features abstract figurative sculptures that merge human forms with elements inspired by medical instruments and hospital architecture. Exploring themes of vulnerability and intervention, her work examines how screening and treatment shape bodily experience, inviting reflection on the complex relationship between the individual, technology, and medical environments. 
   
 Parallel to her studio practice, Krakow engages in text-based and curatorial projects that foster dialogue around themes such as bodily and environmental loss, mirroring as a site of transformation, and displaced or disabled communication. These projects have been presented and published through organizations including The Whitney Museum of American Art, VECTOR Artist Journal, Printed Matter, Thomas Hunter Project Space, Drain Magazine, Lookie Lookie, and Skowhegan Public Programs. 
   
 Krakow earned her MFA from Hunter College and her BA through study at Yale University and the Rhode Island School of Design. She currently teaches sculpture and serves as the director of Mazmanian Gallery at Framingham State University. 
   
 This speaker series is free and open to the public. 
   
 Art Forum  
 Monday, 10/13/25  5:20pm-7pm 
 Calcia Hall, Room 140

title: CALI SCHOOL OF MUSIC: Jazz Drums Masterclass with Billy Hart
description:
Faculty  Jazz Drums  Masterclass with BILLY HART 
 Legendary jazz drummer  Billy Hart ,  known for his work with Herbie Hancock, Stan Getz, and countless others, leads a dynamic masterclass at the Cali School of Music. 
 Billy Hart  is one of the most influential jazz drummers of his generation, celebrated for his versatility across straight-ahead, avant-garde, and popular styles. He has released 12 albums as a leader and appeared on more than 600 recordings, working with legends such as  Herbie Hancock, Miles Davis, Wes Montgomery, Stan Getz,  and  Charles Lloyd.  A founding member of  Quest  and a longtime member of the  Cookers , Hart also leads his own acclaimed quartet. Born in Washington, D.C., he began performing as a teenager with  Buck Hill  and  Shirley Horn  before touring in the 1960s with  Jimmy Smith, Wes Montgomery,  and  Eddie Harris.  Since then, his career has spanned collaborations with both jazz icons and experimental innovators. 
 Don’t miss this rare opportunity to learn from one of the most influential voices in modern jazz drumming!

We are excited to launch the Linguistics Book Club this semester! The goal is to bring folks who like to talk about language and linguistics together to chat about engaging, accessible books that connect to themes in linguistics. 
 Here’s the plan for this fall: 1️⃣ October 13, 2:00–3:00 pm — AlgoSpeak by Adam Aleksic We are sharing this now so you have time to read. We will follow up with the room details closer to the date. 
 All students, undergraduate and graduate, are very welcome. Bring your curiosity, your questions, and your favorite passages. 
 If you are interested, go ahead and start AlgoSpeak. You can access the book through the library!

title: Fade the Stigma: Free Haircuts + Real Conversations
organization: Sigma Lambda Beta International Fraternity Inc.
description:
On Monday, October 13th, the brothers of Sigma Lambda Beta International Fraternity, Inc. will partner with Mane FX Hair Gallery to host a pop-up event offering free haircuts to students in exchange for their participation in a candid conversation about mental health. 
 While receiving their haircut, students will be invited to engage in thoughtful dialogue with fraternity brothers, exploring mental health from both personal and communal perspectives. These conversations aim to foster vulnerability, awareness, and connection within the campus community. 
 Throughout the event, interviews, behind-the-scenes moments, and b-roll footage will be captured to produce a compelling recap and awareness for World Mental Health Awareness video as a tribute to the stories shared and a call to prioritize mental well-being.

 Stop by, sip, and make your voice count!

title: Information Session- Monday, October 13, 2025
description:
The Office of Residence Life is hiring Community Assistants (CA) for the 2026-2027 Academic Year!  
 Applicants are required to attend one of our information sessions.  
 The CA is responsible for the day-to-day interaction and development of the students who reside in the residence halls. CAs live in the halls and supervise a floor or area within the community. CAs take on many roles, such as community builders, role models, peer educators, crisis managers, team players, and administrators. They are student leaders who help our residential students feel acclimated and comfortable on campus. General responsibilities include: maintaining a safe and secure environment for resident students, overnight and weekennd on-call responsibilities, community development, and associated administrative duties.  
   
 To be eligible to apply, you must have a 2.75 or higher semester and cumulative GPA, be in good conduct standing, have at least 50 credits, and be available for all of the student staff training and before and after the semester move-in responsibilities. 
 For more information, visit  our website. 
 If you have any questions, please email ORLjobs@montclair.edu.

title: Threads of Us - Integrative Studio II Student-Led Exhibition
description:
The Department of Art & Design is delighted to announce the Integrative Studio II Student-Led Exhibition for the Fall 2025 semester. This exhibition will feature 3 sections of ISII course:  Threads of Us - Origins,   Pathways , and  New Horizon.  This exhibition will be on view in Finley Gallery from October 07 to November 4, 2025.  The opening reception is Tuesday, Oct. 7 from 2:30-4:30pm.  
   
 The ISII exhibition is the culmination of a six-week journey shared by visual arts majors across three sections of Integrative Studio II. Using the piñata as a point of origin for their investigation, the artists delved deeply into the subject to expand their understanding of its history, materiality, and cultural significance. Building on this initial research, they created artworks across media exploring a range of themes, including construction, deconstruction, regeneration, and transformation. title: Threads of Us - Integrative Studio II Student-Led Exhibition
description:
The Department of Art & Design is delighted to announce the Integrative Studio II Student-Led Exhibition for the Fall 2025 semester. This exhibition will feature 3 sections of ISII course:  Threads of Us - Origins,   Pathways , and  New Horizon.  This exhibition will be on view in Finley Gallery from October 07 to November 4, 2025.  The opening reception is Tuesday, Oct. 7 from 2:30-4:30pm.  
   
 The ISII exhibition is the culmination of a six-week journey shared by visual arts majors across three sections of Integrative Studio II. Using the piñata as a point of origin for their investigation, the artists delved deeply into the subject to expand their understanding of its history, materiality, and cultural significance. Building on this initial research, they created artworks across media exploring a range of themes, including construction, deconstruction, regeneration, and transformation. The student-artists collectively organized this public sharing of their work, together they met the challenge of presenting a visual throughline within the shared gallery spaces while still highlighting the unique voices of each class section. 
   
 SECTION 01:   Pathways   led by Professor Jess Blaustein 
 Andy Bermudez, Christian Campoverde, Rose Perez Cruz, Duy-Minh Do, Steven Jackson, Trevor Jennings, Will Kliment, Valerie Luxama, Tasir Plant, Luz Plata, Emmanuella Ponzio, Daniel Portillo, Denilson Raez, Shyeann Rapley, Fabrizio Rufasto, Giacomo Valerin 
   
 SECTION 02:  Origins   led by Professor Simone Couto 
 Edwin Acevedo, Mari Ahmed, Chez Amos, Rebecca Atwood, Lloyd Zheng, Veronica Avignone, Sarena Campos, Emily Garces, Keaoh Gonzalez, Katelin Guaman, Aj Malabunga, Jenna Mcdonough, Teiona Mcnair, Angeline Ortiz, Dante Ricci, Javier Salas, Ashly Solorzano 
   
 SECTION 03 :  New Horizons   led by Professor Genevieve Lowe 
 Timothy Andras, Janelsy Caceres, Marisol Coliente-izelo, Catalina Ferraro, Matthew Ferraro, Dylan Forbes, Alexa Grasso, Amanda Lerner, Keita Mcfarlane, Melanie Medina, Jeremiah Molin, Kevin Pena, Rosie Santos, Swetha Sivakumar, Diana Valdes, Beyza Yildiz 
   
 Don’t miss your chance to see the work of our talented Art & Design students!

description:

 ts to bring friends along with them. We look forward to sharing in fellowship with our students.

title: Weekly Food Recovery Initiative
description:
Join our weekly Food Recovery events, where dedicated volunteers and members gather to make a difference in our community. Each week, participants help collect perfectly good leftover food from Gourmet Dining and transport it to Blanton. There, the food is repackaged into individual microwavable containers and stocked in the food pantry, providing meals for those in need throughout the week.  
 To Participate : RSVP to attend the event each week. Meet in Blanton Hall Residence Hall Kitchenette in the Communal Area (Tell them you are working with Food Recovery), Sign in via Event Pass and your set! 
 Requirements: 
 
 Volunteers must be Food Safe Certified to participate. 
 Complete the certification by following the step-by-step instructions provided in this  link . 
 Once certified, email your certification to  foodrecoverynetwork@sgamsu.org  to confirm your eligibility to participate. 
 
 Your involvement helps reduce food waste and insecurity while supporting individuals in our community who are in need. We look forward to your participation! *Please Note: This event end time is dependent on the amount of food given. You can estimate for max of hour and a half for recoveries.

title: Threads of Us - Integrative Studio II Student-Led Exhibition
description:
The Department of Art & Design is delighted to announce the Integrative Studio II Student-Led Exhibition for the Fall 2025 semester. This exhibition will feature 3 sections of ISII course:  Threads of Us - Origins,   Pathways , and  New Horizon.  This exhibition will be on view in Finley Gallery from October 07 to November 4, 2025.  The opening reception is Tuesday, Oct. 7 from 2:30-4:30pm.  
   
 The ISII exhibition is the culmination of a six-week journey shared by visual arts majors across three sections of Integrative Studio II. Using the piñata as a point of origin for their investigation, the artists delved deeply into the subject to expand their understanding of its history, materiality, and cultural significance. Building on this initial research, they created artworks across media exploring a range of themes, including construction, deconstruction, regeneration, and transformation. The student-artists collectively organized this public sharing of their work, together they met the challenge of presenting a visual throughline within the shared gallery spaces while still highlighting the unique voices of each class section. 
   
 SECTION 01:   Pathways   led by Professor Jess Blaustein 
 Andy Bermudez, Christian Campoverde, Rose Perez Cruz, Duy-Minh Do, Steven Jackson, Trevor Jennings, Will Kliment, Valerie Luxama, Tasir Plant, Luz Plata, Emmanuella Ponzio, Daniel Portillo, Denilson Raez, Shyeann Rapley, Fabrizio Rufasto, Giacomo Valerin 
   
 SECTION 02:  Origins   led by Professor Simone Couto 
 Edwin Acevedo, Mari Ahmed, Chez Amos, Rebecca Atwood, Lloyd Zheng, Veronica Avignone, Sarena Campos, Emily Garces, Keaoh Gonzalez, Katelin Guaman, Aj Malabunga, Jenna Mcdonough, Teiona Mcnair, Angeline Ortiz, Dante Ricci, Javier Salas, Ashly Solorzano 
   
 SECTION 03 :  New Horizons   led by Professor Genevieve Lowe 
 Timothy Andras, Janelsy Caceres, Marisol Coliente-izelo, Catalina Ferraro, Matthew Ferraro, Dylan Forbes, Alexa Grasso, Amanda Lerner, Keita Mcfarlane, Melanie Medina, Jeremiah Molin, Kevin Pena, Rosie Santos, Swetha Sivakumar, Diana Valdes, Beyza Yildiz 
   
 Don’t miss your chance to see the work of our talented Art & Design students!

title: Panel Discussion
description:
This panel features Afrotectopia founder Ari Melencinao and speakers from the African American Caucus, Disability Caucus, Asian Pacific Islander Caucus, and Gender, Sexuality, and Women's Studies program in a cross-community dialogue about shared advocacy and connected futures. Event will take place within the George Segal Gallery, located on the fourth floor of the Red Hawk Deck parking garage. Admission is free, open to the public. 
   
 
 
 ABOUT THE EXHIBITION 
 September 23 – December 14, 2025 
 Segal Gallery and Kasser Lobby 
 Black Metal  originated as a kitchen table art book that pushes the boundaries of space travel, science fiction, speculative design, Black culture, art, technology, and spirituality. The book emerged from an Afrotectopia-led incubator, in collaboration with MIT Media Lab’s Space Exploration Initiative and NYU’s Interactive Telecommunications Program. The project features contributions from artists Jordan Caldwell, Kordae Jatafa Henry, Jeremy Kamal, and Ari Melenciano. 
 The Age of Black Metal  builds upon the foundational ideas of the book and translates the text into a fully immersive experience for visitors to explore each conceptual chapter–from metaphysical training manuals, botanical consciousness, and self-alignment protocols–through participatory installations. The exhibition is set centuries in the future, imagining a timeline where society has been profoundly shaped by the principles of Black Metal. Ultimately, visitors will not only bear witness to the societal effects of Black Metal, but also leave transformed in some way. 
 The Age of Black Metal  invites all to imagine the futures that Black culture can build, if given space to expand without limit. 
 Ari Melenciano  has cultivated an expansive practice within the arts, technology, design, culture, and pedagogy. Her natural ability to combine many disciplines reveals their interconnectedness and reimagines their conventions for new possibilities. Her art practice ranges from using AI through both critical and imaginative lenses, to sound design using botanical data. Her work has been exhibited around the world from Dubai's Museum of the Future to the Studio Museum in Harlem. She's a frequent international public speaker, and occasionally designs and teaches courses at New York University, Hunter College, Parsons, and the Pratt Institute. 
 Afrotectopia  is a social institution cultivating boundless innovation at the nexus of art, design, technology, and culture. Founded in 2018 by NYU ITP graduate student Ari Melenciano, Afrotectopia began as a highly cross-disciplinary conference cultivating a vibrant community of industry and cultural pioneers. For years, Afrotectopia hosted a variety of programming that bridged connections between emerging technologies, Black culture, and racial equity.

title: Information Session - Wednesday, October 15, 2025
description:
The Office of Residence Life is hiring Community Assistants (CA) for the 2026-2027 Academic Year!  
   
 The CA is responsible for the day-to-day interaction and development of the students who reside in the residence halls. CAs live in the halls and supervise a floor or area within the community. CAs take on many roles, such as community builders, role models, peer educators, crisis managers, team players, and administrators. They are student leaders who help our residential students feel acclimated and comfortable on campus. General responsibilities include: maintaining a safe and secure environment for resident students, overnight and weekennd on-call responsibilities, community development, and associated administrative duties.  
   
 To be eligible to apply, you must have a 2.75 or higher semester and cumulative GPA, be in good conduct standing, have at least 50 credits, and be available for all of the student staff training and before and after the semester move-in responsibilities. 
 For more information, visit  our website. 
 If you have any questions, please email ORLjobs@montclair.edu.

title: WE HOLD THESE TRUTHS: FROM DECLARATION TO FORMING A NATION
description:
The American Experiment is about more than the principles and structures articulated in the Declaration of Independence and the US Constitution. These documents laid out the premises and philosophy of a new nation and the architecture of its government. Over the last 250 years, the United States of America has emerged from this foundation to become a global leader in economic, political, military and cultural terms, built on a framework of core beliefs and practices animated by the challenges, opportunities and crises of our history. 
 Join President Koppell for this lecture on the core features of the American Experiment – with an emphasis on first principles of American democracy such as individual rights, limited power and popular sovereignty. 
 Event is open to all

title: Philosophy for Lunch - “Educating Virtue in Rousseau”
organization: College of Humanities and Social Sciences (CHSS)
description:
• Title: “Educating Virtue in Rousseau” — Philosophy for Lunch 
 • October 16, 2025 
 •  Time : 12:00–1:00PM 
 •  Location : The Cohen Lounge in Dickson Hall (Room 178) 
   
 Description: 
 In  Emile , Jean-Jacques Rousseau explains education as the cultivation of our moral character, above all, our natural self-love— amour-propre —and as necessary to "avoid the pressures of corrupt society," as one scholar put it. Just what he means by self-love, and how he thinks self-love should be cultivated in childhood to make us virtuous and strengthen our ability to resist the corrupting influence of society is important to making sense of his theory. In this week's P4L we will read and discuss passages from the  Emile  not only to understand Rousseau's theory, but also to think critically about the possibilities and limitations of educating virtue today. 
   
 • What is P4L? Students, professors, and other philosophy enthusiasts close-read and discuss a few great passages of philosophy. 
   
 • Who’s invited? No preparation or previous knowledge of philosophy is needed. Everyone is welcome! 
   
 • Should I bring anything? Bring a beverage, and if you're hungry, bring your actual lunch.

title: Roll Up a Sleeve, Save a Life!
description:
Calling all Montclair State faculty, staff, and students—it’s time to be a hero! Join us for our  Blood Drive  in proud partnership with the  American Red Cross  and help make a life-saving impact. Whether you’re a first-time donor or a seasoned pro, your donation can help replenish critical blood supplies used in emergencies, surgeries, and more. It’s quick, easy, and one of the most meaningful ways to give back to your community. 
 So roll up your sleeve, grab a friend, and join us in turning compassion into action—because  every drop counts . Snacks, smiles, and gratitude await!

title: Weekly Food Recovery Initiative
description:
Join our weekly Food Recovery events, where dedicated volunteers and members gather to make a difference in our community. Each week, participants help collect perfectly good leftover food from Gourmet Dining and transport it to Blanton. There, the food is repackaged into individual microwavable containers and stocked in the food pantry, providing meals for those in need throughout the week.  
 To Participate : RSVP to attend the event each week. Meet in Blanton Hall Residence Hall Kitchenette in the Communal Area (Tell them you are working with Food Recovery), Sign in via Event Pass and your set! 
 Requirements: 
 
 Volunteers must be Food Safe Certified to participate. 
 Complete the certification by following the step-by-step instructions provided in this  link . 
 Once certified, email your certification to  foodrecoverynetwork@sgamsu.org  to confirm your eligibility to participate. 
 
 Your involvement helps reduce food waste and insecurity while supporting individuals in our community who are in need. We look forward to your participation! *Please Note: This event end time is dependent on the amount of food given. You can estimate for max of hour and a half for recoveries.

title: (UN)DOING (IN)JUSTICE: A Panel Discussion with Exoneree Lee Clark & the Proof Podcast Team
organization: College of Humanities and Social Sciences (CHSS)
description:
Tina Zottoli (Psychology) will be moderating a panel discussion with the  Proof  podcast team and exoneree Lee Clark. The Proof team uncovered new evidence that ultimately led to the exoneration of Lee and co-defendant Joshua Cane Storey after 25 years of wrongful imprisonment. The audience will get to hear Lee tell his story and share his own perspective on what it was like to have his case taken on by an investigative podcast. The panel will also explore the ethical?issues?faced by storytellers, journalists, and lawyers working in this complex space where the investigation of potential miscarriages of justice is consumed as entertainment.  Most importantly, the event will highlight ways that the average person can support innocence work and help (un)do (in)justice.  
 Registration is required 
 Learn More

title: Nefesh Mountain
description:
New York–based Progressive Americana group Nefesh Mountain Band has emerged as one of the most boundary-pushing ensembles in roots music. Led by the dynamic husband-and-wife team Eric Lindberg and Doni Zasloff, the band has forged a sound entirely their own—blending Americana, bluegrass, folk, jazz, and blues with masterful songwriting, dazzling instrumentals, and fearless creativity. Hailed for their introspective lyrics and world-class musicianship, Nefesh Mountain takes listeners on a deeply personal journey that reflects their wild spirit, compositional finesse, and unbridled love of music. 
   
 Since forming nearly a decade ago, Nefesh Mountain has been proud and vocal about their Jewish American heritage, becoming one of the first prominent Americana/bluegrass bands to weave Jewish tradition and soul into the rich, diverse tapestry of American roots music. 
   
 Their latest album, Beacons, born out of a cross-country tour and shaped by both personal triumphs and turbulent world events, radiates hope, unity, and adventurous genre-bending. Featuring legendary guests Jerry Douglas, Sam Bush, and Stuart Duncan, the record showcases soaring harmonies, heartfelt ballads, and music that speaks to our shared humanity. From the electrified drive of “This Is Me” to the moving grace of “Better Angels,” Nefesh Mountain offers songs that uplift and inspire—serving as a beacon of light in divided times. 
   
 To join us, be sure to pick up your free student ticket from the Alexander Kasser Theatre box office or our mobile box office in the student center lobby, Tuesday - Thursday, 11:30 AM to 2:00 PM, and show your student ID at the PEAK desk in the lobby when you arrive for a surprise gift from PEAK.

 " And they devoted themselves to the apostles' teaching and the fellowship, to the breaking of bread and the prayers.   And awe came upon every soul, and many wonders and signs were being done through the apostles.   And all who believed were together and had all things in common.   And they were selling their possessions and belongings and distributing the proceeds to all, as any had need.   And day by day, attending the temple together and breaking bread in their homes, they received their food with glad and generous hearts,  praising God and having favor with all the people. And the Lord added to their number day by day those who were being saved." - Acts 2:42-47

description:

As databases have become larger, searching has actually become more difficult to do well without knowing more about how these databases are being developed and managed today. We’ll discuss using Boolean searching tools to manipulate search results, how to engage with database thesauri and a controlled vocabulary, linked subject headings, setting up search alerts, and more.

title: Threads of Us - Integrative Studio II Student-Led Exhibition
description:
The Department of Art & Design is delighted to announce the Integrative Studio II Student-Led Exhibition for the Fall 2025 semester. This exhibition will feature 3 sections of ISII course:  Threads of Us - Origins,   Pathways , and  New Horizon.  This exhibition will be on view in Finley Gallery from October 07 to November 4, 2025.  The opening reception is Tuesday, Oct. 7 from 2:30-4:30pm.  
   
 The ISII exhibition is the culmination of a six-week journey shared by visual arts majors across three sections of Integrative Studio II. Using the piñata as a point of origin for their investigation, the artists delved deeply into the subject to expand their understanding of its history, materiality, and cultural significance. Building on this initial research, they created artworks across media exploring a range of themes, including construction, deconstruction, regeneration, and transformation. The student-artists collectively organized this public sharing of their work, together they met the challenge of presenting a visual throughline within the shared gallery spaces while still highlighting the unique voices of each class section. 
   
 SECTION 01:   Pathways   led by Professor Jess Blaustein 
 Andy Bermudez, Christian Campoverde, Rose Perez Cruz, Duy-Minh Do, Steven Jackson, Trevor Jennings, Will Kliment, Valerie Luxama, Tasir Plant, Luz Plata, Emmanuella Ponzio, Daniel Portillo, Denilson Raez, Shyeann Rapley, Fabrizio Rufasto, Giacomo Valerin 
   
 SECTION 02:  Origins   led by Professor Simone Couto 
 Edwin Acevedo, Mari Ahmed, Chez Amos, Rebecca Atwood, Lloyd Zheng, Veronica Avignone, Sarena Campos, Emily Garces, Keaoh Gonzalez, Katelin Guaman, Aj Malabunga, Jenna Mcdonough, Teiona Mcnair, Angeline Ortiz, Dante Ricci, Javier Salas, Ashly Solorzano 
   
 SECTION 03 :  New Horizons   led by Professor Genevieve Lowe 
 Timothy Andras, Janelsy Caceres, Marisol Coliente-izelo, Catalina Ferraro, Matthew Ferraro, Dylan Forbes, Alexa Grasso, Amanda Lerner, Keita Mcfarlane, Melanie Medina, Jeremiah Molin, Kevin Pena, Rosie Santos, Swetha Sivakumar, Diana Valdes, Beyza Yildiz 
   
 Don’t miss your chance to see the work of our talented Art & Design students!

title: Crash-A-Class Fall 2025
description:
Ever wonder what it's like in that class everyone's been talking about? Curious about what you'll learn in different majors across campus? You're in luck! 
   
 Running  Monday, October 13 through Friday, October 17 ,  "Crash-A-Class"  is the perfect opportunity to experience and explore different courses you may consider taking in the future and with Fall 2025 Registration  right around the corner , there's no better time to try!  
   
 CLICK HERE TO CHECK OUT THE SELECTION OF COURSES & SIGN UP TODAY! 
   
 "Crash-a-Class" is an exclusive opportunity for students to sit in on a class for a day to learn more about specific programs from a seat  right inside  the classroom! Held just before spring registration, this program offers students a chance to try out a class  before  registering for it for the coming semester! Like what you've learned? Consider trying out another course in the same subject or speaking with your academic advisor to learn more about adding it to your academic plan!  
   
 "Crash-a-Class" is a free program hosted by University College in collaboration with all of the unrestricted, undergraduate Colleges and Schools on campus. There is no fee or penalty to attend or participate. Students participating in "Crash-a-Class"  will not be excused from their regularly scheduled classes  to attend a course they've registered to "crash."

title: Teaching Italian Symposium XVIII: Toolkit italiano: Building Innovative Pathways to Success
organization: College of Humanities and Social Sciences (CHSS)
description:
The 18th annual professional development program organized by the Coccia Institute for the Italian Experience in America and Prof.ssa Enza Antenos, Dept. of World Languages & Cultures, at Montclair State University. This year’s event will be held on  Friday, October 17, 9:00 am-3:30 pm , in the University Hall Conference Center (7th Floor) at Montclair State University. The annual unveiling of the national Coccia-Inserra Award for Excellence and Innovation in the Teaching of Italian (K-12) will be presented on this occasion. 
 The  registration  fee will be $80 for teachers of Italian and $30 for graduate students/prospective teachers. Registration fee includes Luncheon and Parking. 
 We are looking forward to welcoming back past attendees and greeting new members of the teaching community! Please go ahead and  register  even if you have not as yet received formal authorization from your school district/Board of Ed – we understand that it takes time! 
 REGISTER TODAY! 
 If any questions arise, please do not hesitate to contact Mark Rotella, the Director of the Coccia Institute for the Italian Experience in America, at rotellam@montclair.edu or Cristina Latino, Program Coordinator of the Coccia Institute, at latinoc@montclair.edu.

title: Our Strength, Our Story: Immigrants & the Fight for Justice
location: School Of Business 321 - Active Learning FHT Classroom
description: The event is targeted towards educating students in Montclair regarding immigrant issue and how their contribution to society often goes unheard of. This event is meant to draw light towards these communities and is a method of reaching out to students on campus. The purpose of this teaching is not only to educate, but it also promote community as many of our fellow classmates are first-generation Americans. In this event we'll touch upon multiple topics: 1. How immigrants contribute to the country and their purpose. 2. The REAL truth behind the border and the "immigrant issue." 3. Lastly, ICE's impact on cultural groups, and their impact on communities. This discussion will be student-led and student-taught.

description:
Coffeehouse is our live music event where students can sign up to perform in Russ Lounge. Whether you’re playing, singing, or just coming to hang out, it’s always a great night of creativity and community. 
   
 The goal of the event is to turn Russ Lounge into a performance space that can accommodate an audience, but it’s also a hands-on opportunity to learn how to set up a performance from start to finish. We will be mixing on a Midas M32R, so it's also an opportunity to learn how digital mixers for live audio work. All that prep work culminates in a show featuring Montclair State students from 7 PM to 9:15 PM. We go through the process of setup, performance, and breakdown. IF this interests you, please fill out  this form  for more information on how to join the crew. 
   
 For those interested in performing in the upcoming coffeehouse, we implore you to fill out  this google form , all applicants will receive an email with the setlist once all responses have been sent out!

title: Abandoned Jungle Habitat Hike
description:
Join us on a walk through an abandoned Jungle Habitat that was owned by the Warner Bros. located in West Milford, NJ. This habitat opened in the summer of 1972 and closed in the fall of 1976. During the time this place was open there was a drive through safari where it was typical animals would go on top of cars. There were also times where animals would escape their enclosure or cause injury. Walk around areas that have old enclosures for animals and see what is left of the habitat! 
 How do I sign-up? 
 
 Registration Opens on Fusion on September 22, 2025. 
 Register online through  Fusion , in the Student Recreation Center’s main office, or over the phone (973-655-3340). 
 Cost for Students $10 
 
 Where and when? 
 
 Saturday, October 18, 2025 
 10:00 am – 5:00 pm 
 Begins at Student Recreation Center 
 
 What to bring:  Water, lunch, weather appropriate clothing, boots or sneakers, and sunscreen. 
 Potential Hazards:  Poisonous plants/allergies; insect bites; unpredictable weather changes; sunburn/heat exhaustion; dehydration; steep, rocky and/or slippery terrain; rolling or falling rocks; snakes and large animals; and injuries including sprains/strains, abrasions, lacerations and fractures.

title: Threads of Us - Integrative Studio II Student-Led Exhibition
description:
The Department of Art & Design is delighted to announce the Integrative Studio II Student-Led Exhibition for the Fall 2025 semester. This exhibition will feature 3 sections of ISII course:  Threads of Us - Origins,   Pathways , and  New Horizon.  This exhibition will be on view in Finley Gallery from October 07 to November 4, 2025.  The opening reception is Tuesday, Oct. 7 from 2:30-4:30pm.  
   
 The ISII exhibition is the culmination of a six-week journey shared by visual arts majors across three sections of Integrative Studio II. Using the piñata as a point of origin for their investigation, the artists delved deeply into the subject to expand their understanding of its history, materiality, and cultural significance. Building on this initial research, they created artworks across media exploring a range of themes, including construction, deconstruction, regeneration, and transformation. The student-artists collectively organized this public sharing of their work, together they met the challenge of presenting a visual throughline within the shared gallery spaces while still highlighting the unique voices of each class section. 
   
 SECTION 01:   Pathways   led by Professor Jess Blaustein 
 Andy Bermudez, Christian Campoverde, Rose Perez Cruz, Duy-Minh Do, Steven Jackson, Trevor Jennings, Will Kliment, Valerie Luxama, Tasir Plant, Luz Plata, Emmanuella Ponzio, Daniel Portillo, Denilson Raez, Shyeann Rapley, Fabrizio Rufasto, Giacomo Valerin 
   
 SECTION 02:  Origins   led by Professor Simone Couto 
 Edwin Acevedo, Mari Ahmed, Chez Amos, Rebecca Atwood, Lloyd Zheng, Veronica Avignone, Sarena Campos, Emily Garces, Keaoh Gonzalez, Katelin Guaman, Aj Malabunga, Jenna Mcdonough, Teiona Mcnair, Angeline Ortiz, Dante Ricci, Javier Salas, Ashly Solorzano 
   
 SECTION 03 :  New Horizons   led by Professor Genevieve Lowe 
 Timothy Andras, Janelsy Caceres, Marisol Coliente-izelo, Catalina Ferraro, Matthew Ferraro, Dylan Forbes, Alexa Grasso, Amanda Lerner, Keita Mcfarlane, Melanie Medina, Jeremiah Molin, Kevin Pena, Rosie Santos, Swetha Sivakumar, Diana Valdes, Beyza Yildiz 
   
 Don’t miss your chance to see the work of our talented Art & Design students!

title: Free Swim Lessons *Beginner*
description:
Never swam before? No problem! These lessons will give you the important foundational skills in swimming and help you be more comfortable in the pool. Learn how to use proper breath control, float, and swim with a kickboard.  
 Skills Focus: 
 
 Being comfortable in the water 
 Learning how to float on your back and front 
 Learning how to kick off the wall with a kickboard 
 Introducing proper breath control in the water 
 Learning how to tread water 
 Learn alternate kicks (Froggy Kick) 
 Being comfortable in the deep end  
 Introducing arms to your strokes

title: Montclair Unraveled General Body Meeting!!!
description:
Do you want to learn a new knitting or crochet pattern? Do you want to make a cool craft but can't pick one or figure out where to start? Then come to the Montclair Unraveled!  
 Join us and learn how to make something new like accessories, decor, or plushies! Already have something you're working on? Feel free to make some progress here! All are welcome, whether you have the most craft experience possible or none at all. Come by and enjoy the company of others who share your passions for the fiber arts!

title: Cultural Competency in Psychology
description: Step into the world of  cultural competency  a must-have skill for anyone pursuing psychology or a helping profession. This event will dive into how beliefs, customs, and values shape people’s lives, and how future practitioners can better serve diverse communities with respect and understanding. With insight from a guest speaker, you’ll gain practical knowledge and perspectives that will prepare you to work effectively across cultures and grow as both a student and a professional.

The student-artists collectively organized this public sharing of their work, together they met the challenge of presenting a visual throughline within the shared gallery spaces while still highlighting the unique voices of each class section.

title: New Jersey Small Business Summit
organization: Feliciano Center for Entrepreneurship and Innovation
description:
Ready to level up your entrepreneurial game? 
 Join us for the  second annual New Jersey Small Business Summit  on  Wednesday, October 22, 2025  right here at Montclair State University! This isn't your typical boring business conference – it's an interactive expo where you'll actually connect with real entrepreneurs and learn skills that matter. 
 Whether you're already running a side hustle, dreaming of starting your own business, or just curious about the entrepreneurial world, this summit has something for you. You'll discover how to future-proof any business idea and master AI tools that can seriously boost your productivity and sales game. 
 What's in it for you: 
 
 Breakout sessions and panels with successful entrepreneurs who've been where you are 
 An inspiring keynote from Lloyd Pearson (Founder of Lloyd Pearson | Live With Lloyd) 
 "Expert Corner" – free 15-minute one-on-one sessions with industry pros (perfect for getting advice on your ideas!) 
 Student vendor showcases (see what your peers are building!) 
 Personalized learning tracks so you can focus on what interests you most 
 Tons of networking opportunities (translation: meet people who could change your career path) 
 
 Plus, we've got you covered with free breakfast and lunch – because nobody learns well on an empty stomach. 
 This event sold out last year, so grab your FREE ticket now if you want to walk away with real strategies and connections that could kickstart your future.

title: Threads of Us - Integrative Studio II Student-Led Exhibition
description:
The Department of Art & Design is delighted to announce the Integrative Studio II Student-Led Exhibition for the Fall 2025 semester. This exhibition will feature 3 sections of ISII course:  Threads of Us - Origins,   Pathways , and  New Horizon.  This exhibition will be on view in Finley Gallery from October 07 to November 4, 2025.  The opening reception is Tuesday, Oct. 7 from 2:30-4:30pm.  
   
 The ISII exhibition is the culmination of a six-week journey shared by visual arts majors across three sections of Integrative Studio II. Using the piñata as a point of origin for their investigation, the artists delved deeply into the subject to expand their understanding of its history, materiality, and cultural significance. Building on this initial research, they created artworks across media exploring a range of themes, including construction, deconstruction, regeneration, and transformation. The student-artists collectively organized this public sharing of their work, together they met the challenge of presenting a visual throughline within the shared gallery spaces while still highlighting the unique voices of each class section. 
   
 SECTION 01:   Pathways   led by Professor Jess Blaustein 
 Andy Bermudez, Christian Campoverde, Rose Perez Cruz, Duy-Minh Do, Steven Jackson, Trevor Jennings, Will Kliment, Valerie Luxama, Tasir Plant, Luz Plata, Emmanuella Ponzio, Daniel Portillo, Denilson Raez, Shyeann Rapley, Fabrizio Rufasto, Giacomo Valerin 
   
 SECTION 02:  Origins   led by Professor Simone Couto 
 Edwin Acevedo, Mari Ahmed, Chez Amos, Rebecca Atwood, Lloyd Zheng, Veronica Avignone, Sarena Campos, Emily Garces, Keaoh Gonzalez, Katelin Guaman, Aj Malabunga, Jenna Mcdonough, Teiona Mcnair, Angeline Ortiz, Dante Ricci, Javier Salas, Ashly Solorzano 
   
 SECTION 03 :  New Horizons   led by Professor Genevieve Lowe 
 Timothy Andras, Janelsy Caceres, Marisol Coliente-izelo, Catalina Ferraro, Matthew Ferraro, Dylan Forbes, Alexa Grasso, Amanda Lerner, Keita Mcfarlane, Melanie Medina, Jeremiah Molin, Kevin Pena, Rosie Santos, Swetha Sivakumar, Diana Valdes, Beyza Yildiz 
   
 Don’t miss your chance to see the work of our talented Art & Design students!

title: Montclair State University Wing Chun Club Training
organization: Montclair State University Wing Chun Club
description: The practicing and learning of Wing Chun, a martial art that originated in China over two hundred years ago. In this training individuals will learn this martial art, build up relationships with other members in class, and gain a deeper appreciation for this aspect of Chinese culture. Training sessions will typically include learning of forms, learning fundamentals of movement, incorporating said fundamental motions into various drills.

title: Apple Picking
description:
Join us at Wightman Farms for a day at the orchard in the beautiful fall weather. There is a farm market which has salads, sandwiches, prepared foods, fresh produce, farm baked goods, cider, and ice cream. Bring money if you plan to buy apples that you picked. 
 How do I Sign-up? 
 
 Please register on  Fusion , or in the Student Rec Center main office, or over the phone (973-655-3340). 
 Cost for Students $10 
 
 Where and When?

title: Threads of Us - Integrative Studio II Student-Led Exhibition
description:
The Department of Art & Design is delighted to announce the Integrative Studio II Student-Led Exhibition for the Fall 2025 semester. This exhibition will feature 3 sections of ISII course:  Threads of Us - Origins,   Pathways , and  New Horizon.  This exhibition will be on view in Finley Gallery from October 07 to November 4, 2025.  The opening reception is Tuesday, Oct. 7 from 2:30-4:30pm.  
   
 The ISII exhibition is the culmination of a six-week journey shared by visual arts majors across three sections of Integrative Studio II. Using the piñata as a point of origin for their investigation, the artists delved deeply into the subject to expand their understanding of its history, materiality, and cultural significance. Building on this initial research, they created artworks across media exploring a range of themes, including construction, deconstruction, regeneration, and transformation. The student-artists collectively organized this public sharing of their work, together they met the challenge of presenting a visual throughline within the shared gallery spaces while still highlighting the unique voices of each class section. 
   
 SECTION 01:   Pathways   led by Professor Jess Blaustein 
 Andy Bermudez, Christian Campoverde, Rose Perez Cruz, Duy-Minh Do, Steven Jackson, Trevor Jennings, Will Kliment, Valerie Luxama, Tasir Plant, Luz Plata, Emmanuella Ponzio, Daniel Portillo, Denilson Raez, Shyeann Rapley, Fabrizio Rufasto, Giacomo Valerin 
   
 SECTION 02:  Origins   led by Professor Simone Couto 
 Edwin Acevedo, Mari Ahmed, Chez Amos, Rebecca Atwood, Lloyd Zheng, Veronica Avignone, Sarena Campos, Emily Garces, Keaoh Gonzalez, Katelin Guaman, Aj Malabunga, Jenna Mcdonough, Teiona Mcnair, Angeline Ortiz, Dante Ricci, Javier Salas, Ashly Solorzano 
   
 SECTION 03 :  New Horizons   led by Professor Genevieve Lowe 
 Timothy Andras, Janelsy Caceres, Marisol Coliente-izelo, Catalina Ferraro, Matthew Ferraro, Dylan Forbes, Alexa Grasso, Amanda Lerner, Keita Mcfarlane, Melanie Medina, Jeremiah Molin, Kevin Pena, Rosie Santos, Swetha Sivakumar, Diana Valdes, Beyza Yildiz 
   
 Don’t miss your chance to see the work of our talented Art & Design students!

description:

title: Safe Space Training
description:
Our Safe Space Training is an intensive, interactive training that provides attendees with information and tools to combat homophobia, biphobia, transphobia, cissexism and heterosexism, on campus and beyond. Through interactive activities and discussion, participants will personally reflect on their own experiences to enhance their personal and professional development, provide further education, and finally, identify ways to create change on campus and beyond. 
 All sessions are three hours and are first-come, first-served. Pre-registration is required. Registrants are expected to attend the full session. Only individuals who have fully completed the Safe Space Program and have agreed to the expectations of its membership are able to display the sticker/button of our program. Refreshments are not provided; however, you are more than welcome to bring your lunch, coffee, snacks, etc.

title: Korematsu v. The United States - History Club Crisis Sim and GBM
organization: The Historical Society at Montclair State
description:
Step into history with the History Club's immersive crisis simulation based on the landmark Supreme Court case Korematsu v. United States. 
 Become a Supreme Court Justice, an ACLU Lawyer, or a Department of Justice official to debate tough questions about our rights and national security, and experience firsthand the challenges faced during this pivotal moment in history. 
 This event is a unique chance to dive deep, think critically, and engage with history like never before. 
 Don't know about the case, don't worry! This is an engaging and immersive way to learn about one of the most important Supreme Court cases in American history. Free pizza will be available to all participants!

title: Information Session- Monday, October 27, 2025
description:
The Office of Residence Life is hiring Community Assistants (CA) for the 2026-2027 Academic Year!  
   
 The CA is responsible for the day-to-day interaction and development of the students who reside in the residence halls. CAs live in the halls and supervise a floor or area within the community. CAs take on many roles, such as community builders, role models, peer educators, crisis managers, team players, and administrators. They are student leaders who help our residential students feel acclimated and comfortable on campus. General responsibilities include: maintaining a safe and secure environment for resident students, overnight and weekennd on-call responsibilities, community development, and associated administrative duties.  
   
 To be eligible to apply, you must have a 2.75 or higher semester and cumulative GPA, be in good conduct standing, have at least 50 credits, and be available for all of the student staff training and before and after the semester move-in responsibilities. 
 For more information, visit  our website. 
 If you have any questions, please email ORLjobs@montclair.edu.

title: Skills for Success: The Truth About Soft Skills
description:
Think success in college and beyond is all about technical know-how? Think again! This interactive workshop uncovers the real power of soft skills—like communication, teamwork, problem-solving, conflict resolution, and adaptability—that employers and professors alike value most. Through hands-on activities and real-world examples, you’ll learn how to recognize, strengthen, and showcase these essential skills to thrive as a student and future professional. 
 Event Details:  📅 Date: Tuesday, October 28, 2025 🕒 Time: 1 - 2 pm 📍 Location: Susan A. Cole Hall, Suite 340 (3rd Floor) 
 Presented by the University College Academic Programming Team

title: Weekly Food Recovery Initiative
description:
Join our weekly Food Recovery events, where dedicated volunteers and members gather to make a difference in our community. Each week, participants help collect perfectly good leftover food from Gourmet Dining and transport it to Blanton. There, the food is repackaged into individual microwavable containers and stocked in the food pantry, providing meals for those in need throughout the week.  
 To Participate : RSVP to attend the event each week. Meet in Blanton Hall Residence Hall Kitchenette in the Communal Area (Tell them you are working with Food Recovery), Sign in via Event Pass and your set! 
 Requirements: 
 
 Volunteers must be Food Safe Certified to participate. 
 Complete the certification by following the step-by-step instructions provided in this  link . 
 Once certified, email your certification to  foodrecoverynetwork@sgamsu.org  to confirm your eligibility to participate. 
 
 Your involvement helps reduce food waste and insecurity while supporting individuals in our community who are in need. We look forward to your participation! *Please Note: This event end time is dependent on the amount of food given. You can estimate for max of hour and a half for recoveries.

title: The Big 3 Competition
location: Student Recreation Center 1101 - First Floor Fitness
description:
Built Different? Show Us - The big 3 lifts (Deadlift, Squat, and Bench Press) are the foundation of true strength, and now it is your time to dominate the platform. Whether you’re lifting for the glory, the prizes, or just to beat your PR this is your chance to push your limits and have fun, all while getting to utilize our brand new strength equipment! 
   
 
 How are results scored? 
 
 Maximum 5 repetitions 
 1 attempt per lift after a warm-up set 
 Scoring calculation: Weight lifted x repetitions divided by body weight 
 Final score will be total of 3 lifts  combined 
 
 
   
 How do I sign up? 
 
 Registration is not required 
 FREE for students with a valid Montclair State ID 
 
 Where and When? 
 
 Tuesday, October 28

description:
We’re thrilled to invite you to our General Body Meetings! This is a fantastic opportunity to get involved, meet fellow members, and learn about the exciting plans and initiatives we have in store. 
 - Get to know the team, hear about our mission, and understand the goals and vision for this year. We’ll also introduce key members and roles within the organization. 
 - Learn about upcoming events, projects, and opportunities for involvement. We'll outline our plans and how you can contribute to our success. 
 - Connect with other members, make new friends, and build relationships within our community.  
 - Find out how you can volunteer, join committees, or participate in special projects. We’ll provide information on various roles and how you can make an impact. 
 Whether you’re a new member or a returning one, your presence and participation will help shape the future of our organization.  
 We look forward to meeting you and embarking on this exciting journey together!

title: CALI SCHOOL MIDWEEK SERIES: Immersive Residency Guest Violinist Stefan Jackiw - Performance
description:
2:00 PM  Cali Midweek Series: Stefan Jackiw  Leshowitz Recital Hall, Chapin Hall, Cali School of Music 
 Stefan Jackiw  performs solo violin works and the dynamic opening movement of Mendelssohn’s String Octet with Cali Graduate String Students. Hailed for playing that “combines poetry and purity with impeccable technique” (Boston Globe), Jackiw has appeared with leading U.S. symphonies, tours internationally, and is a founding member of the Junction Trio. Artistic Director of the Hawaii Chamber Music Festival, his performances are praised as intelligent, sensitive, and deeply moving. Leshowitz Recital Hall, Chapin Hall, Cali School of Music 
 FREE TICKETS 
 More about Stefan Jackiw's Cali Immersive Residency Schedule

title: Honoring the Ancestors
location: University Hall 1010 - James B. Todd Lecture Hall
description: This event is a cultural and educational experience celebrating the traditions of Día de los Muertos. Attendees will learn about the holiday’s Indigenous and Mexican roots through a guest presentation, engage with an interactive ofrenda exhibit, and participate in hands-on crafts that reflect the holiday’s symbols of remembrance and celebration. Tables will be arranged for crafts, with craft materials provided. We expect attendees to participate by contributing items or memory cards to the altar, engaging in the presentation, and joining the craft activities. The flow is designed to be both reflective and interactive, encouraging audience participation throughout.

title: Weekly Food Recovery Initiative
description:
Join our weekly Food Recovery events, where dedicated volunteers and members gather to make a difference in our community. Each week, participants help collect perfectly good leftover food from Gourmet Dining and transport it to Blanton. There, the food is repackaged into individual microwavable containers and stocked in the food pantry, providing meals for those in need throughout the week.  
 To Participate : RSVP to attend the event each week. Meet in Blanton Hall Residence Hall Kitchenette in the Communal Area (Tell them you are working with Food Recovery), Sign in via Event Pass and your set! 
 Requirements: 
 
 Volunteers must be Food Safe Certified to participate. 
 Complete the certification by following the step-by-step instructions provided in this  link . 
 Once certified, email your certification to  foodrecoverynetwork@sgamsu.org  to confirm your eligibility to participate. 
 
 Your involvement helps reduce food waste and insecurity while supporting individuals in our community who are in need. We look forward to your participation! *Please Note: This event end time is dependent on the amount of food given. You can estimate for max of hour and a half for recoveries.
