title: SLAM General Body Meeting
description: SLAM General Body Meetings are open to all undergraduate students at  Montclair State University and Bloomfield College  who are interested in getting involved. These meetings are a space for volunteers and members to connect, hear important updates from the Executive Board, and learn about upcoming events and opportunities. General Body Meetings are also a chance for students to share their ideas, contribute to event planning, and build community on campus. Attending regularly helps volunteers stay informed and gain priority for event participation and leadership opportunities throughout the year.

title: Free Swim Lessons - Intermediate
description:
Take your swimming to the next level! Get introduced to new strokes or work on the ones you already know. These lessons are for swimmers who are a little more comfortable in the water but still want to improve their technique and expand what skills they know.  
 Skills Focus: 
 
 Swimming unassisted on your front and back  
 Improve treading (in the deep end) 
 Improving breath control in the water

 Introduction to and/or improving your breaststroke

 Introduction to open and flip turns 
 Introduction to Butterfly

description: Join us for an engaging  Crisis Management Workshop  where you'll learn how to navigate high-pressure situations and protect a brand’s reputation during a crisis. This session will cover key principles of effective crisis response, communication strategies, and decision-making under stress. Participants will take part in a hands-on  PR statement activity , where you’ll craft and present a public response to a simulated crisis scenario. This interactive exercise will help build your confidence, sharpen your messaging skills, and prepare you for real-world challenges in media and public relations.

title: Cru Large Group!
description:
Cru is a caring community passionate about connecting people to Jesus Christ!  Join us in learning together on Who Christ is, building a personal relationship with Him, and joining a community filled with love and open arms!  
 This semester we will be focusing on the theme: "The Fruits of the Spirit". We pray that our students will learn about the Fruits of the Spirit in the Bible and be able to bear good fruit in their walk with God.  
 " And they devoted themselves to the apostles' teaching and the fellowship, to the breaking of bread and the prayers.   And awe came upon every soul, and many wonders and signs were being done through the apostles.   And all who believed were together and had all things in common.   And they were selling their possessions and belongings and distributing the proceeds to all, as any had need.   And day by day, attending the temple together and breaking bread in their homes, they received their food with glad and generous hearts,  praising God and having favor with all the people. And the Lord added to their number day by day those who were being saved." - Acts 2:42-47

title: FRN Tabling Meet & Connect
description:
👻 Join us for a fun and festive opportunity to learn more about our organization at our special Halloween-themed table! Stop by to meet our team, learn about our mission and programs, and find out how you can get involved—all while enjoying some sweet seasonal activities. 
 Test your knowledge with  Trick-or-Treat Trivia -  answer a quick question about food waste or sustainability, and if you get it right, you’ll score a treat from our giant Halloween candy bowl! 
 Try your luck with our  “Guess How Many Seeds” Jar -  guess how many roasted pumpkin seeds are inside for a chance to win a fun eco-friendly prize like a tote bag, sticker pack, or reusable utensil. 
 Plus, take home some creative  DIY Spooky Stickers  featuring Halloween designs and food recovery slogans like  “No Tricks, Just Treats—Don’t Waste Food”  and  “Scary Amount of Food Waste.” 
 🎃 Candy bags will be available while supplies last, so come early! 
 💬 Chat with our team, ask questions, and get involved in our upcoming events. We look forward to sharing some Halloween cheer, and some knowledge, with you!

title: “Sweatober" Challenge Month
description:
Are you ready to commit to your goals, try something new, and earn rewards while you sweat? All October long, we’re turning up the energy with Sweatober—a month-long group fitness challenge designed to keep you moving, motivated, and having fun.   Plus, this is a judgment-free zone: no matter your fitness level, our instructors and community are here to cheer you on. It’s not about being perfect, it’s about showing up for yourself! 
 Here’s how it works:   
 Attend group fitness classes throughout the month and earn class points toward a t-shirt.   Stay consistent and have a blast working out with us.  Attend 10 classes of your choosing  (like Zumba, Kickboxing, Yoga, HIIT, Pilates, Cycling, BJJ, and more!) over the course of the month and you’ll be snagging a FREE exclusive t-shirt as prize!  We'll contact you when you hit the goal so there's nothing you need to do; simply show up with your ID. 
   
 Let October be the month you commit to YOU. One class at a time. 
 When:  October 1-31 (month-long) - Reminder, there will be no classes Saturday, 10/18- Saturday, 10/25 for Fall Break- 
 Where:  Student Recreation Center, MP1 and MP2 (Locations depend on the fall group x schedule) 
 Who:  Montclair Students Drop-in is welcomed!

title: Lakota Wolf Preserve
description:
We will enjoy a ½ mile nature walk in Columbia, NJ to a preserve, where we will be invited into an observation area surrounded by 4 packs of wolves! We will also get the opportunity to observe Lakota’s foxes, bobcats, and lynx! 
   
 How do I sign-up? 
 
 Register online through Fusion, in the Student Recreation Center's main office, or over the phone (973-655-3340). 
 Cost for Students $10 
 
   
 Where and when? 
 
 Sunday, November 2, 2025 
 1:00 pm - 5:30 pm 
 Begins at Student Recreation Center 
 
   
 What to bring:  Water, lunch, long pants, sneakers, and sunscreen. 
   
 Potential Hazards:  Unpredictable weather changes, sunburn/heat exhaustion, dehydration, allergic reactions/poisonous plants, insect bites and injury by running, including sprains, lacerations, abrasions and fractures.

description: Join us as we celebrate the rich history, traditions, and vibrancy of Haiti! This event will highlight Haitian culture through music, dance, art, and food, giving students an opportunity to experience the heart of the island. From Kompa rhythms and Creole expressions to traditional dishes and cultural displays, the night will be filled with learning, community, and celebration. Whether you have Haitian roots or simply want to explore and appreciate a new culture, this event is open to all. Come ready to enjoy, connect, and celebrate Haiti!

title: Information Session-  Monday, November 3, 2025
description:
The Office of Residence Life is hiring Community Assistants (CA) for the 2026-2027 Academic Year!  
   
 The CA is responsible for the day-to-day interaction and development of the students who reside in the residence halls. CAs live in the halls and supervise a floor or area within the community. CAs take on many roles, such as community builders, role models, peer educators, crisis managers, team players, and administrators. They are student leaders who help our residential students feel acclimated and comfortable on campus. General responsibilities include: maintaining a safe and secure environment for resident students, overnight and weekennd on-call responsibilities, community development, and associated administrative duties.  
   
 To be eligible to apply, you must have a 2.75 or higher semester and cumulative GPA, be in good conduct standing, have at least 50 credits, and be available for all of the student staff training and before and after the semester move-in responsibilities. 
 For more information, visit  our website. 
 If you have any questions, please email ORLjobs@montclair.edu.

title: Weekly Food Recovery Initiative
description:
Join our weekly Food Recovery events, where dedicated volunteers and members gather to make a difference in our community. Each week, participants help collect perfectly good leftover food from Gourmet Dining and transport it to Blanton. There, the food is repackaged into individual microwavable containers and stocked in the food pantry, providing meals for those in need throughout the week.  
 To Participate : RSVP to attend the event each week. Meet in Blanton Hall Residence Hall Kitchenette in the Communal Area (Tell them you are working with Food Recovery), Sign in via Event Pass and your set! 
 Requirements: 
 
 Volunteers must be Food Safe Certified to participate. 
 Complete the certification by following the step-by-step instructions provided in this  link . 
 Once certified, email your certification to  foodrecoverynetwork@sgamsu.org  to confirm your eligibility to participate. 
 
 Your involvement helps reduce food waste and insecurity while supporting individuals in our community who are in need. We look forward to your participation! *Please Note: This event end time is dependent on the amount of food given. You can estimate for max of hour and a half for recoveries.

title: Dia de Los Muertos
location: Student Center 250ABC - Ballrooms A, B, and C
description:
Join us in honoring and celebrating the rich tradition of  Día de los Muertos , a vibrant Mexican holiday that commemorates the lives of loved ones who have passed. Our event will feature a beautifully decorated altar ( ofrenda ), live music, traditional dances, face painting, arts and crafts, and delicious food that captures the spirit of the season. 
 Together, we’ll create a space of remembrance, community, and joy—celebrating life through culture, tradition, and unity. All are welcome to participate, whether to learn, to remember, or to simply enjoy this colorful and meaningful celebration.

title: Black Metal Film Screening
description:
This special screening of the film adaptation of  Black Metal  is followed by a discussion with artist and curator Ari Melenciano. 
 
 
 ABOUT THE EXHIBITION Segal Gallery and Kasser Lobby September 23 – December 14, 2025 
 Black Metal  originated as a kitchen table art book that pushes the boundaries of space travel, science fiction, speculative design, Black culture, art, technology, and spirituality. The book emerged from an Afrotectopia-led incubator, in collaboration with MIT Media Lab’s Space Exploration Initiative and NYU’s Interactive Telecommunications Program. The project features contributions from artists Jordan Caldwell, Kordae Jatafa Henry, Jeremy Kamal, and Ari Melenciano. 
 The Age of Black Metal  builds upon the foundational ideas of the book and translates the text into a fully immersive experience for visitors to explore each conceptual chapter–from metaphysical training manuals, botanical consciousness, and self-alignment protocols–through participatory installations. The exhibition is set centuries in the future, imagining a timeline where society has been profoundly shaped by the principles of Black Metal. Ultimately, visitors will not only bear witness to the societal effects of Black Metal, but also leave transformed in some way.

title: CSAM Science Teaching Program - Program Meeting
description:
The  CSAM Science Teaching Program  holds  biweekly meetings  that are open, welcoming, and inclusive! Any student curious about science teaching is invited to join us. Each meeting highlights a theme related to science education, from classroom strategies to career pathways, and offers students opportunities to connect with mentors, explore internships, and gain real-world experience working with teachers and children. Students are encouraged to  bring a guest  who may also be interested in exploring science teaching. 
 These gatherings help us build a strong  community of support , where students encourage one another, share experiences, and access valuable opportunities such as  scholarships, paid internships, and mentoring  from advanced peers and in-service science teachers. Whether you are just beginning to explore the idea of teaching or already on the path toward certification, these meetings are a place to grow, learn, and belong.

title: MSW Program Virtual Current Student Panel
description:
Discover What’s Possible in Our MSW Program Our  MSW program  prepares leaders in social work to help children, youth and families in a diverse local and global society. The program aims to prepare advanced practitioners to provide a range of clinical and advocacy services to vulnerable children, adolescents and their families. We're hosting a   virtual current student panel November 5 at 7:00 PM (EST) . This is a no-pressure, exploratory space to meet our team and determine if our program fits your goals. Program Snapshot 
 
 Credits: On-campus and  online  - 60 | Advanced Standing - 33 
 Program Length: 2 - 4 years  
 Modality: On-campus or online  
 Cohort: Day option or evening option ( synchronous and asynchronous in online program ) 
 
 Meet the Panelists  
 
 Allegra Addeo, Maywood School District 
 Alanna Matos, St. Mary's General Hospital 
 Tim Nee, Mental Health Association, Center for Behavioral Health 
 Skyler Segal, Mental Health Association of Essex/Morris

title: Weekly Food Recovery Initiative
description:
Join our weekly Food Recovery events, where dedicated volunteers and members gather to make a difference in our community. Each week, participants help collect perfectly good leftover food from Gourmet Dining and transport it to Blanton. There, the food is repackaged into individual microwavable containers and stocked in the food pantry, providing meals for those in need throughout the week.  
 To Participate : RSVP to attend the event each week. Meet in Blanton Hall Residence Hall Kitchenette in the Communal Area (Tell them you are working with Food Recovery), Sign in via Event Pass and your set! 
 Requirements: 
 
 Volunteers must be Food Safe Certified to participate. 
 Complete the certification by following the step-by-step instructions provided in this  link . 
 Once certified, email your certification to  foodrecoverynetwork@sgamsu.org  to confirm your eligibility to participate. 
 
 Your involvement helps reduce food waste and insecurity while supporting individuals in our community who are in need. We look forward to your participation! *Please Note: This event end time is dependent on the amount of food given. You can estimate for max of hour and a half for recoveries.

title: RULE OF LAW AND THE CORE AMERICAN INSTITUTIONS
description:
The Declaration of Independence lays out a legalistic argument for separation from Great Britain. With this start, the founders placed the primacy of law as bedrock principle of a new nation. Many of the features ultimately enshrined in the Constitution rest upon this base including separation of powers, checks and balances, judicial independence, federalism and state’s rights. Our system of market capitalism stems from the same starting point with an emphasis on property rights, contract and state enforcement. 
 Join President Koppell for a lecture and discussion tracing rule of law as a through-line of American democracy that predates the founding of the United States and has served as the logic model for the conflicts and controversies that have shaped the American experiment. 
 Event is open to all

title: Cru Large Group!
description:
Cru is a caring community passionate about connecting people to Jesus Christ!  Join us in learning together on Who Christ is, building a personal relationship with Him, and joining a community filled with love and open arms!  
 This semester we will be focusing on the theme: "The Fruits of the Spirit". We pray that our students will learn about the Fruits of the Spirit in the Bible and be able to bear good fruit in their walk with God.  
 " And they devoted themselves to the apostles' teaching and the fellowship, to the breaking of bread and the prayers.   And awe came upon every soul, and many wonders and signs were being done through the apostles.   And all who believed were together and had all things in common.   And they were selling their possessions and belongings and distributing the proceeds to all, as any had need.   And day by day, attending the temple together and breaking bread in their homes, they received their food with glad and generous hearts,  praising God and having favor with all the people. And the Lord added to their number day by day those who were being saved." - Acts 2:42-47

title: Horseback Riding Trip
description:
Learn horseback riding basics at the Echo Lakes Stable. We'll go on a gorgeous trail ride through beautiful fields and trails that follow  the path next to mountain sides with swiftly running streams. NOTE: WEIGHT LIMIT 225lb 
   
 How do I sign-up? 
 
 Register online through  Fusion , in the Student Recreation Center's main office, or over the phone (973-655-3340). 
 Cost for Students $20 
 
   
 Where and when? 
 
 Saturday, November 8th, 2025 
 9:30 a.m. - 3 p.m. 
 Begins at Student Recreation Center 
 
   
 What to bring:  Water, lunch, long pants, sneakers/boots and sunscreen. 
 Potential Hazards:  Unpredictable weather changes, sunburn/heat exhaustion, dehydration, allergic reactions/poisonous plants, insect bites and injury by running, including sprains, lacerations, abrasions and fractures, injuries by animal including bites, falls from height and injuries from hooves including kicks and steps.

title: South Mountain Preserve Easy Hike (Fairy Hike)
description:
Get ready to frolic amongst the fairies as we go through the South Mountain preserve fairy trail, decorated with woodland creature houses along our beautiful walk through nature. As you join us on this magical hike, make sure to wear comfortable sneakers or hiking shoes and bring a water bottle! 
   
 How do I sign-up? 
 
 Register online through Fusion, in the Student Recreation Center's main office, or over the phone (973-655-3340) . 
 Cost for Students $10 
 
   
 Where and when? 
 
 Sunday, November 9, 2025 
 10:00 am - 5:00 pm  
 Begins at Student Recreation Center 
 
   
 What to bring:  Water, lunch, weather appropriate clothing, boots or sneakers, and sunscreen. 
 Potential Hazards:  Poisonous plants/allergies; insect bites; unpredictable weather changes; sunburn/heat exhaustion; dehydration; steep, rocky and/or slippery terrain; rolling or falling rocks; snakes and large animals; and injuries including sprains/strains, abrasions, lacerations and fractures.

title: Free Swim Lessons - *Beginner*
description:
Never swam before? No problem! These lessons will give you the important foundational skills in swimming and help you be more comfortable in the pool. Learn how to use proper breath control, float, and swim with a kickboard.  
 Skills Focus: 
 
 Being comfortable in the water 
 Learning how to float on your back and front 
 Learning how to kick off the wall with a kickboard 
 Introducing proper breath control in the water 
 Learning how to tread water 
 Learn alternate kicks (Froggy Kick) 
 Being comfortable in the deep end  
 Introducing arms to your strokes 
 
 How do I Sign-up? 
 
 Registration is not required 
 FREE with valid Montclair State ID 
 
 When and Where? 
 
 From 09/8 - 11/20 
 Mondays, 9-10 a.m. 
 Student Recreation Center - Pool

title: Empanada Sale
description:
Empanada Fundraiser Sale! 🌟 Support a great cause and enjoy delicious, homemade empanadas! 
 The Hermanos Of La Unidad Latina, Lambda Upsilon Lambda Fraternity Inc., are hosting a special empanada sale to raise funds for our Spring 2025 scholarship and The Florence Immigrant & Refugee Rights Project. Every bite helps make a difference! 
 🥟 What’s on the menu? 
 
 
 Beef Empanadas 
 
 
 Chicken Empanadas 
 
 
 Cheese Empanadas 
 
 
   
 💵 Price: $3 each or $5 for 2 
 Come hungry, bring your friends, and help us reach our fundraising goal—one empanada at a time! 
 The Hermanos Of La Unidad Latina, Lambda Upsilon Lambda Fraternity Inc.

title: MS Analytics and Certificate Virtual Information Session
description:
Step Into the Fastest-Growing Field in Business Montclair’s  MS in Business Analytics  is built for professionals who are ready to lead with insight, not just information. This program goes beyond technical training—it’s about transforming data into strategy and becoming the voice decision-makers trust. This session will also cover the specialized analytics programs we offer: 
 
 Business Analytics Graduate Certificate 
 Digital Marketing Analytics (MS) 
 Human Resource Analytics (MS) 
 
 Join us for a virtual information session November 10 at 12:00 PM (EST)  and discover how we'll prepare you to lead in this high-growth field.

title: Free Swim Lessons - Intermediate
description:
Take your swimming to the next level! Get introduced to new strokes or work on the ones you already know. These lessons are for swimmers who are a little more comfortable in the water but still want to improve their technique and expand what skills they know.  
 Skills Focus: 
 
 Swimming unassisted on your front and back  
 Improve treading (in the deep end) 
 Improving breath control in the water 
 Learn alternate kicks (Dolphin Kick) 
 Introduction to and/or improving your breaststroke 
 Swimming laps 
 Introduction to open and flip turns 
 Introduction to Butterfly 
 
 How do I Sign-up? 
 
 Registration is not required 
 FREE with valid Montclair State ID 
 
 When and Where? 
 
 From 09/8 - 11/20 
 Mondays, 1-2 p.m and 5-6 p.m.

title: Montclair Unraveled General Body Meeting!!!
description:
Do you want to learn a new knitting or crochet pattern? Do you want to make a cool craft but can't pick one or figure out where to start? Then come to the Montclair Unraveled!  
 Join us and learn how to make something new like accessories, decor, or plushies! Already have something you're working on? Feel free to make some progress here! All are welcome, whether you have the most craft experience possible or none at all. Come by and enjoy the company of others who share your passions for the fiber arts!

title: First Gen Drop-In Group
description:
This is a support drop-in group for first generation college students aimed to help ensure that first-gen students are empowered and prepared to reach their full social, professional, and academic potential. Students will have opportunities to build community, empower and support one another through shared experiences with topics that may include, but not limited to, lack of knowledge about college experience/resources, imposter syndrome, financial and family stress, academic struggles and other challenging subject matters. 
 Group Meets: 
 
 First group will be held on September 9, 2025 
 On Tuesdays from 11:30am – 12:30pm in the Health Promotion Drop-In Center 
 
 For more information, contact group leaders Ms. Charisma Jackson, LCSW at  jacksoncha@montclair.edu

title: Weekly Food Recovery Initiative
description:
Join our weekly Food Recovery events, where dedicated volunteers and members gather to make a difference in our community. Each week, participants help collect perfectly good leftover food from Gourmet Dining and transport it to Blanton. There, the food is repackaged into individual microwavable containers and stocked in the food pantry, providing meals for those in need throughout the week.  
 To Participate : RSVP to attend the event each week. Meet in Blanton Hall Residence Hall Kitchenette in the Communal Area (Tell them you are working with Food Recovery), Sign in via Event Pass and your set! 
 Requirements: 
 
 Volunteers must be Food Safe Certified to participate. 
 Complete the certification by following the step-by-step instructions provided in this  link . 
 Once certified, email your certification to  foodrecoverynetwork@sgamsu.org  to confirm your eligibility to participate. 
 
 Your involvement helps reduce food waste and insecurity while supporting individuals in our community who are in need. We look forward to your participation! *Please Note: This event end time is dependent on the amount of food given. You can estimate for max of hour and a half for recoveries.

title: SA Awareness & Prevention with the Sisters of  Phi Sigma Sigma & Theta Phi Alpha
location: University Hall 1070 - Phyllis & Gerald LeBoff Lecture Hall
description:
Join the sisters of Phi Sigma Sigma and Theta Phi Alpha for an important evening focused on sexual assault awareness, prevention, and empowerment. This collaborative event is dedicated to fostering a safe, supportive, and informed campus community. 
 Through educational resources and guest speakers. Attendees will gain valuable insights into consent, bystander intervention, and how to support survivors. Our goal is to create a space for open dialogue, learning, and collective action against sexual violence. 
 Whether you're seeking knowledge, resources, or ways to get involved, this event welcomes all students to be part of the conversation and the movement toward a safer community!

description:
We’re thrilled to invite you to our General Body Meetings! This is a fantastic opportunity to get involved, meet fellow members, and learn about the exciting plans and initiatives we have in store. 
 - Get to know the team, hear about our mission, and understand the goals and vision for this year. We’ll also introduce key members and roles within the organization.

 - Find out how you can volunteer, join committees, or participate in special projects. We’ll provide information on various roles and how you can make an impact. 
 Whether you’re a new member or a returning one, your presence and participation will help shape the future of our organization.  
 We look forward to meeting you and embarking on this exciting journey together!

title: Information Session- Wednesday, November 12, 2025
description:
The Office of Residence Life is hiring Community Assistants (CA) for the 2026-2027 Academic Year!  
   
 The CA is responsible for the day-to-day interaction and development of the students who reside in the residence halls. CAs live in the halls and supervise a floor or area within the community. CAs take on many roles, such as community builders, role models, peer educators, crisis managers, team players, and administrators. They are student leaders who help our residential students feel acclimated and comfortable on campus. General responsibilities include: maintaining a safe and secure environment for resident students, overnight and weekennd on-call responsibilities, community development, and associated administrative duties.  
   
 To be eligible to apply, you must have a 2.75 or higher semester and cumulative GPA, be in good conduct standing, have at least 50 credits, and be available for all of the student staff training and before and after the semester move-in responsibilities. 
 For more information, visit  our website. 
 If you have any questions, please email ORLjobs@montclair.edu.

title: Weekly Food Recovery Initiative
description:
Join our weekly Food Recovery events, where dedicated volunteers and members gather to make a difference in our community. Each week, participants help collect perfectly good leftover food from Gourmet Dining and transport it to Blanton. There, the food is repackaged into individual microwavable containers and stocked in the food pantry, providing meals for those in need throughout the week.  
 To Participate : RSVP to attend the event each week. Meet in Blanton Hall Residence Hall Kitchenette in the Communal Area (Tell them you are working with Food Recovery), Sign in via Event Pass and your set! 
 Requirements: 
 
 Volunteers must be Food Safe Certified to participate. 
 Complete the certification by following the step-by-step instructions provided in this  link . 
 Once certified, email your certification to  foodrecoverynetwork@sgamsu.org  to confirm your eligibility to participate. 
 
 Your involvement helps reduce food waste and insecurity while supporting individuals in our community who are in need. We look forward to your participation! *Please Note: This event end time is dependent on the amount of food given. You can estimate for max of hour and a half for recoveries.

title: Fireside Chats
description:
Hang out and have casual conversations about anything and everything with other students while enjoying refreshments! Join us on Thursdays from 3:15-4:15pm.  
 What are Fireside Chats: 
 
 A space for students to meet, connect, and have a casual conversation about a given topic, or anything else that feels comfortable for everyone else. It can be about the school climate, student life in general, or your favorite show. All students are welcome!

title: Clinical Psychology (MA) Virtual Information Session
description:
Transform Lives With A  Career In Clinical Psychology 
 Montclair's Clinical Psychology program combines advanced education with practical experience. Whether you’re interested in working in private practice or research, we’ll walk you through the wide range of career paths available for clinical psychology graduates. We offer two  STEM-Designated  concentrations within our rigorous Master's program, tailored to your unique practice objectives: 
 
 Clinical Psychology, Child/Adolescent Psychology Concentration (MA) Students in the child/adolescent concentration learn about the unique psychological needs of children and adolescents, as well as developmental considerations in psychopathology, assessment, and treatment, including the role of family and social contexts. This concentration is designed to prepare students for MA-level clinical positions in mental health settings, particularly those that serve children and families.    
 Clinical Psychology, Forensic Psychology Concentration (MA) The Forensic Psychology concentration is designed to prepare students to offer master’s level clinical services to legal system-involved populations in settings that do not require licensure. Such settings include mental health and drug court settings, offender rehabilitation programs, child and family advocacy settings and bona fide public service agencies exempted by state boards of psychological examiners for non-doctoral providers. 
 
 Ready to learn more? Join us for a  virtual information session on November 13 at 5:30 PM (EST)  to explore Montclair's programs in Clinical Psychology and speak directly with our faculty.

title: Cru Large Group!
description:
Cru is a caring community passionate about connecting people to Jesus Christ!  Join us in learning together on Who Christ is, building a personal relationship with Him, and joining a community filled with love and open arms!  
 This semester we will be focusing on the theme: "The Fruits of the Spirit". We pray that our students will learn about the Fruits of the Spirit in the Bible and be able to bear good fruit in their walk with God.  
 " And they devoted themselves to the apostles' teaching and the fellowship, to the breaking of bread and the prayers.   And awe came upon every soul, and many wonders and signs were being done through the apostles.   And all who believed were together and had all things in common.   And they were selling their possessions and belongings and distributing the proceeds to all, as any had need.   And day by day, attending the temple together and breaking bread in their homes, they received their food with glad and generous hearts,  praising God and having favor with all the people. And the Lord added to their number day by day those who were being saved." - Acts 2:42-47

title: Free Trip to the National Museum of the American Indian
organization: The Historical Society at Montclair State
location: The National Museum of the American Indian
description:
In honor of National Native American Heritage Month, The History Club is taking a trip to the Smithsonian’s National Museum of the American Indian at the historic Alexander Hamilton U.S. Custom House in Lower Manhattan. 
 Students will have the chance to explore powerful exhibitions that highlight the histories, traditions, and contemporary voices of Native peoples from across the Americas. From art and artifacts to modern storytelling, this visit is a unique opportunity to celebrate Indigenous heritage and reflect on the lasting impact of Native nations.

title: RA+P and Residence Life Coffee House Night
description:
Coffeehouse is our live music event where students can sign up to perform in Russ Lounge. Whether you’re playing, singing, or just coming to hang out, it’s always a great night of creativity and community. 
   
 The goal of the event is to turn Russ Lounge into a performance space that can accommodate an audience, but it’s also a hands-on opportunity to learn how to set up a performance from start to finish. We will be mixing on a Midas M32R, so it's also an opportunity to learn how digital mixers for live audio work. All that prep work culminates in a show featuring Montclair State students from 7 PM to 9:15 PM. We go through the process of setup, performance, and breakdown. IF this interests you, please fill out  t his form  for more information on how to join the crew. 
   
 For those interested in performing in the upcoming coffeehouse, we implore you to fill out  this google form , all applicants will receive an email  with the setlist once all responses have been sent out! 
   
 See you soon, stay groovy!! 
   
 All students are welcome, commuters need to be signed in a with a resident following Residence Life guest registration procedures.

title: Fall of the Berlin Wall - History Club Crisis Sim and GBM
organization: The Historical Society at Montclair State
description:
Step into one of the most pivotal moments of the Cold War with the History Club! Through a mix of roleplaying, interactive activities, and a short history lesson, you’ll get the chance to experience how key figures shaped global events and influenced the world we live in today. 
 No background knowledge is required! This is a fun and engaging way to dive into history, think critically about big decisions, and explore the human side of world-changing moments. 
 All students are welcome to join, and free pizza will be available to everyone who stops by!

title: Information Session- Monday, November 17, 2025
description:
The Office of Residence Life is hiring Community Assistants (CA) for the 2026-2027 Academic Year!  
   
 The CA is responsible for the day-to-day interaction and development of the students who reside in the residence halls. CAs live in the halls and supervise a floor or area within the community. CAs take on many roles, such as community builders, role models, peer educators, crisis managers, team players, and administrators. They are student leaders who help our residential students feel acclimated and comfortable on campus. General responsibilities include: maintaining a safe and secure environment for resident students, overnight and weekennd on-call responsibilities, community development, and associated administrative duties.  
   
 To be eligible to apply, you must have a 2.75 or higher semester and cumulative GPA, be in good conduct standing, have at least 50 credits, and be available for all of the student staff training and before and after the semester move-in responsibilities. 
 For more information, visit  our website. 
 If you have any questions, please email ORLjobs@montclair.edu.

title: International Education Week: Rep Your Flag
description:
This is your chance to represent your home country and your familial roots in International Education Week's  Rep Your Flag Event . We are hosting an event on  November 17th from 2:30-4pm in Student Center Ballrooms A and B  to kick off international education week and celebrate our students from around the globe.  
   
 This will be an event with tables where individuals can celebrate their culture, connect with peers and departments, play music, and ultimately celebrate the global community that makes Montclair so rich.  
   
 
 There is no requirement in terms of what you bring as we understand that every financial situation is different, however, if you have something that you believe represents your culture please bring it to share with the Montclair community!

title: First Gen Drop-In Group
description:
This is a support drop-in group for first generation college students aimed to help ensure that first-gen students are empowered and prepared to reach their full social, professional, and academic potential. Students will have opportunities to build community, empower and support one another through shared experiences with topics that may include, but not limited to, lack of knowledge about college experience/resources, imposter syndrome, financial and family stress, academic struggles and other challenging subject matters. 
 Group Meets: 
 
 First group will be held on September 9, 2025 
 On Tuesdays from 11:30am – 12:30pm in the Health Promotion Drop-In Center 
 
 For more information, contact group leaders Ms. Charisma Jackson, LCSW at  jacksoncha@montclair.edu

title: Weekly Food Recovery Initiative
description:
Join our weekly Food Recovery events, where dedicated volunteers and members gather to make a difference in our community. Each week, participants help collect perfectly good leftover food from Gourmet Dining and transport it to Blanton. There, the food is repackaged into individual microwavable containers and stocked in the food pantry, providing meals for those in need throughout the week.  
 To Participate : RSVP to attend the event each week. Meet in Blanton Hall Residence Hall Kitchenette in the Communal Area (Tell them you are working with Food Recovery), Sign in via Event Pass and your set! 
 Requirements: 
 
 Volunteers must be Food Safe Certified to participate. 
 Complete the certification by following the step-by-step instructions provided in this  link . 
 Once certified, email your certification to  foodrecoverynetwork@sgamsu.org  to confirm your eligibility to participate. 
 
 Your involvement helps reduce food waste and insecurity while supporting individuals in our community who are in need. We look forward to your participation! *Please Note: This event end time is dependent on the amount of food given. You can estimate for max of hour and a half for recoveries.

description:

title: CSAM Science Teaching Program - Program Meeting
description:
The  CSAM Science Teaching Program  holds  biweekly meetings  that are open, welcoming, and inclusive! Any student curious about science teaching is invited to join us. Each meeting highlights a theme related to science education, from classroom strategies to career pathways, and offers students opportunities to connect with mentors, explore internships, and gain real-world experience working with teachers and children. Students are encouraged to  bring a guest  who may also be interested in exploring science teaching. 
 These gatherings help us build a strong  community of support , where students encourage one another, share experiences, and access valuable opportunities such as  scholarships, paid internships, and mentoring  from advanced peers and in-service science teachers. Whether you are just beginning to explore the idea of teaching or already on the path toward certification, these meetings are a place to grow, learn, and belong.

title: Information Session- Wednesday, November 19, 2025
description:
The Office of Residence Life is hiring Community Assistants (CA) for the 2026-2027 Academic Year!  
   
 The CA is responsible for the day-to-day interaction and development of the students who reside in the residence halls. CAs live in the halls and supervise a floor or area within the community. CAs take on many roles, such as community builders, role models, peer educators, crisis managers, team players, and administrators. They are student leaders who help our residential students feel acclimated and comfortable on campus. General responsibilities include: maintaining a safe and secure environment for resident students, overnight and weekennd on-call responsibilities, community development, and associated administrative duties.  
   
 To be eligible to apply, you must have a 2.75 or higher semester and cumulative GPA, be in good conduct standing, have at least 50 credits, and be available for all of the student staff training and before and after the semester move-in responsibilities. 
 For more information, visit  our website. 
 If you have any questions, please email ORLjobs@montclair.edu.

title: Free Swim Lessons - Intermediate
description:
Take your swimming to the next level! Get introduced to new strokes or work on the ones you already know. These lessons are for swimmers who are a little more comfortable in the water but still want to improve their technique and expand what skills they know.  
 Skills Focus: 
 
 Swimming unassisted on your front and back  
 Improve treading (in the deep end) 
 Improving breath control in the water 
 Learn alternate kicks (Dolphin Kick) 
 Introduction to and/or improving your breaststroke 
 Swimming laps 
 Introduction to open and flip turns 
 Introduction to Butterfly 
 
 How do I Sign-up? 
 
 Registration is not required 
 FREE with valid Montclair State ID 
 
 When and Where? 
 
 From 09/8 - 11/20 
 Thursday: 11-12PM and 4-5PM 
 Student Recreation Center - Pool

title: Free Swim Lessons *Beginner*
description:
Never swam before? No problem! These lessons will give you the important foundational skills in swimming and help you be more comfortable in the pool. Learn how to use proper breath control, float, and swim with a kickboard.  
 Skills Focus: 
 
 Being comfortable in the water 
 Learning how to float on your back and front 
 Learning how to kick off the wall with a kickboard 
 Introducing proper breath control in the water 
 Learning how to tread water 
 Learn alternate kicks (Froggy Kick) 
 Being comfortable in the deep end  
 Introducing arms to your strokes 
 
 How do I Sign-up? 
 
 Registration is not required 
 FREE with a valid Montclair State ID 
 
 When and Where? 
 
 From 09/8 - 11/20 
 Thursday:11-12 PM and 4-5PM 
 Student Recreation Center - Pool

title: Safe Space Training
description:
Our Safe Space Training is an intensive, interactive training that provides attendees with information and tools to combat homophobia, biphobia, transphobia, cissexism and heterosexism, on campus and beyond. Through interactive activities and discussion, participants will personally reflect on their own experiences to enhance their personal and professional development, provide further education, and finally, identify ways to create change on campus and beyond. 
 All sessions are three hours and are first-come, first-served. Pre-registration is required. Registrants are expected to attend the full session. Only individuals who have fully completed the Safe Space Program and have agreed to the expectations of its membership are able to display the sticker/button of our program. Refreshments are not provided; however, you are more than welcome to bring your lunch, coffee, snacks, etc.

title: Weekly Food Recovery Initiative
description:
Join our weekly Food Recovery events, where dedicated volunteers and members gather to make a difference in our community. Each week, participants help collect perfectly good leftover food from Gourmet Dining and transport it to Blanton. There, the food is repackaged into individual microwavable containers and stocked in the food pantry, providing meals for those in need throughout the week.  
 To Participate : RSVP to attend the event each week. Meet in Blanton Hall Residence Hall Kitchenette in the Communal Area (Tell them you are working with Food Recovery), Sign in via Event Pass and your set! 
 Requirements: 
 
 Volunteers must be Food Safe Certified to participate. 
 Complete the certification by following the step-by-step instructions provided in this  link . 
 Once certified, email your certification to  foodrecoverynetwork@sgamsu.org  to confirm your eligibility to participate. 
 
 Your involvement helps reduce food waste and insecurity while supporting individuals in our community who are in need. We look forward to your participation! *Please Note: This event end time is dependent on the amount of food given. You can estimate for max of hour and a half for recoveries.

title: Fireside Chats
description:
Hang out and have casual conversations about anything and everything with other students while enjoying refreshments! Join us on Thursdays from 3:15-4:15pm.  
 What are Fireside Chats: 
 
 A space for students to meet, connect, and have a casual conversation about a given topic, or anything else that feels comfortable for everyone else. It can be about the school climate, student life in general, or your favorite show. All students are welcome!

title: Educational Leadership (MA) Virtual Information Session
description:
Become the leader our schools need   If you’ve thought about the next step in your education career - whether that means becoming a principal, stepping into an admin role, or just making a bigger impact - we want to meet you.  Our Educational Leadership program is built for professionals like you who want to lead with purpose, create change, and shape the future of schools and students. We're hosting an  Educational Leadership (MA) Virtual Information Session November 20 at 5:00 PM (EST) . This is a no-pressure, exploratory space to meet our team and determine if our program fits your goals. This session will cover the following programs:  
 
 Educational Leadership (MA)   Online, Fast Track, Core Choice, and Offsite 
 Supervisor Certification 
 Principal Certification 
 Director of School Counseling Services Certification

description:
Have you ever tried to walk on water before? I'm sure if you did it didn't work out too well… but come on down to the SRC pool you will be able to achieve that dream! You won’t want to miss out on a once in a lifetime opportunity!

title: Child Advocacy (MA) Faculty Perspectives: Advocating for Children in 2025
description:
Lead Change in Child Advocacy and Policy   When children and families face complex challenges, they need informed, compassionate professionals to stand up, speak out, and shape solutions. If you're ready to turn your commitment into action, we're here to help.  We're hosting a  virtual panel on November 20 at 6:00 PM (EST) . This is a no-pressure, exploratory space to meet our faculty and determine if our program fits your goals. This session will cover the following programs:  
 
 Online Master of Arts in Child Advocacy and Policy 
 Child Advocacy (Certificate) – Online 
 
 Why Montclair?  Completing the certificate program allows you to transfer all 15 credits towards the Master of Arts in Child Advocacy, in accordance with all related graduate policy.

description:

title: Cru Large Group!
description:
Cru is a caring community passionate about connecting people to Jesus Christ!  Join us in learning together on Who Christ is, building a personal relationship with Him, and joining a community filled with love and open arms!  
 This semester we will be focusing on the theme: "The Fruits of the Spirit". We pray that our students will learn about the Fruits of the Spirit in the Bible and be able to bear good fruit in their walk with God.  
 " And they devoted themselves to the apostles' teaching and the fellowship, to the breaking of bread and the prayers.   And awe came upon every soul, and many wonders and signs were being done through the apostles.   And all who believed were together and had all things in common.   And they were selling their possessions and belongings and distributing the proceeds to all, as any had need.   And day by day, attending the temple together and breaking bread in their homes, they received their food with glad and generous hearts,  praising God and having favor with all the people. And the Lord added to their number day by day those who were being saved." - Acts 2:42-47

title: Turtle Back Zoo
description:
Join your friends for a day at the Zoo! See animals from all over the world as you enjoy lunch at your choice of cafes around the park. Bring cash for lunch, a water bottle to stay hydrated, and comfortable walking shoes. 
   
 How do I sign-up? 
 
 Register online through Fusion, in the Student Recreation Center's main office, or over the phone (973-655-3340) . 
 Cost for Students  $10 
 
   
 Where and when? 
 
 Saturday, November 22, 2025 
 10:00 am - 4:00 pm 
 Begins at Student Recreation Center 
 
   
 What to bring:  Water, lunch, long pants, sneakers, and sunscreen.   Participants MUST wear sneakers in order to go on the zipline and obstacle course. 
   
 Note:  Tree Top Adventures restricts obstacle course and zipline participants to a strict weight limit of 250 lbs. Students may opt to participate in only the Zoo portion of the trip should they like. 
 Potential Hazards:  Unpredictable weather changes, sunburn/heat exhaustion, dehydration, allergic reactions/poisonous plants, insect bites and injury by running, including sprains, lacerations, abrasions and fractures.

title: Montclair Unraveled General Body Meeting!!!
description:
Do you want to learn a new knitting or crochet pattern? Do you want to make a cool craft but can't pick one or figure out where to start? Then come to the Montclair Unraveled!  
 Join us and learn how to make something new like accessories, decor, or plushies! Already have something you're working on? Feel free to make some progress here! All are welcome, whether you have the most craft experience possible or none at all. Come by and enjoy the company of others who share your passions for the fiber arts!

title: PASO General Board Meeting
description:
Join us every week for our PASO General Board Meetings, where culture, community, and leadership come together! These meetings are open to all members and students interested in learning more about Peruvian culture, supporting Latinx representation, and getting involved.

title: First Gen Drop-In Group
description:
This is a support drop-in group for first generation college students aimed to help ensure that first-gen students are empowered and prepared to reach their full social, professional, and academic potential. Students will have opportunities to build community, empower and support one another through shared experiences with topics that may include, but not limited to, lack of knowledge about college experience/resources, imposter syndrome, financial and family stress, academic struggles and other challenging subject matters. 
 Group Meets: 
 
 First group will be held on September 9, 2025 
 On Tuesdays from 11:30am – 12:30pm in the Health Promotion Drop-In Center 
 
 For more information, contact group leaders Ms. Charisma Jackson, LCSW at  jacksoncha@montclair.edu

title: Weekly Food Recovery Initiative
description:
Join our weekly Food Recovery events, where dedicated volunteers and members gather to make a difference in our community. Each week, participants help collect perfectly good leftover food from Gourmet Dining and transport it to Blanton. There, the food is repackaged into individual microwavable containers and stocked in the food pantry, providing meals for those in need throughout the week.  
 To Participate : RSVP to attend the event each week. Meet in Blanton Hall Residence Hall Kitchenette in the Communal Area (Tell them you are working with Food Recovery), Sign in via Event Pass and your set! 
 Requirements: 
 
 Volunteers must be Food Safe Certified to participate. 
 Complete the certification by following the step-by-step instructions provided in this  link . 
 Once certified, email your certification to  foodrecoverynetwork@sgamsu.org  to confirm your eligibility to participate. 
 
 Your involvement helps reduce food waste and insecurity while supporting individuals in our community who are in need. We look forward to your participation! *Please Note: This event end time is dependent on the amount of food given. You can estimate for max of hour and a half for recoveries.

title: Audiology (AuD) Virtual Information Session
description:
Our  Audiology program  is designed to empower you to excel in multiple roles—clinician, educator, administrator, and researcher. 
 
 As a clinician, you'll be able to identify the hearing health needs of individuals and design, implement and evaluate treatment plans to meet those needs.  
 In education, you'll be equipped to share your knowledge and inspire others in community healthcare settings. 
 As an administrator, you'll learn to lead, innovate, and elevate audiology services across diverse environments. 
 And with a strong foundation in research, you'll be ready to explore new frontiers in audiology, applying cutting-edge insights directly to your practice. 
 
 Join us for a virtual information session November 25 at 7:00 PM (EST)  to become a versatile leader in the dynamic field of audiology, where your impact can resonate for a lifetime.

title: E PLURIBUS UNUM
description:
The Latin phrase “E pluribus unum” (Out of many, one) is the motto on the Great Seal of the United States. Originally representing the unity of the thirteen colonies forming a single nation, the phrase expanded to encapsulate the idea that we can be a single people with varied backgrounds and histories. In both ways, this motto has often been more aspiration than description. 
 In this final lecture, President Koppell explores what makes us one nation. Is it simply a legal definition, a shared heritage or commitment to a set of ideals? How do we function as a unified nation when the framers fractured power purposely? What are the features of the U.S. that have bonded communities and institutions together in the face of divisive forces? 
 Event is open to all

title: Kichwa Language and Culture Workshop Series - 2nd Edition
organization: Center for Latino Heritage & Spanish Language Excellence
description:
After a very successful first edition of our Kichwa Language and Culture classes last spring, we are thrilled to launch a new workshop series starting September 15. This year’s program continues to pair Kichwa language learning with rich cultural experiences: and we’re adding something special. Students will have the opportunity to engage with an acclaimed Indigenous artist, exploring their paintings, the deep connection to nature behind their work, the meaning of colors and subjects, and more. 
 
 Space is limited.  
 Class is starting on Monday, September 15th, every Monday from 5:30pm-7:30pm for the duration of 10 weeks. 
 REGISTRATION IS REQUIRED by contacting Dr. Calarota-Ninman at calarotaa@montclair.edu

title: Weekly Food Recovery Initiative
description:
Join our weekly Food Recovery events, where dedicated volunteers and members gather to make a difference in our community. Each week, participants help collect perfectly good leftover food from Gourmet Dining and transport it to Blanton. There, the food is repackaged into individual microwavable containers and stocked in the food pantry, providing meals for those in need throughout the week.  
 To Participate : RSVP to attend the event each week. Meet in Blanton Hall Residence Hall Kitchenette in the Communal Area (Tell them you are working with Food Recovery), Sign in via Event Pass and your set! 
 Requirements: 
 
 Volunteers must be Food Safe Certified to participate. 
 Complete the certification by following the step-by-step instructions provided in this  link . 
 Once certified, email your certification to  foodrecoverynetwork@sgamsu.org  to confirm your eligibility to participate. 
 
 Your involvement helps reduce food waste and insecurity while supporting individuals in our community who are in need. We look forward to your participation! *Please Note: This event end time is dependent on the amount of food given. You can estimate for max of hour and a half for recoveries.

title: CSAM Science Teaching Program - Program Meeting
description:
The  CSAM Science Teaching Program  holds  biweekly meetings  that are open, welcoming, and inclusive! Any student curious about science teaching is invited to join us. Each meeting highlights a theme related to science education, from classroom strategies to career pathways, and offers students opportunities to connect with mentors, explore internships, and gain real-world experience working with teachers and children. Students are encouraged to  bring a guest  who may also be interested in exploring science teaching. 
 These gatherings help us build a strong  community of support , where students encourage one another, share experiences, and access valuable opportunities such as  scholarships, paid internships, and mentoring  from advanced peers and in-service science teachers. Whether you are just beginning to explore the idea of teaching or already on the path toward certification, these meetings are a place to grow, learn, and belong.

description:
Hang out and have casual conversations about anything and everything with other students while enjoying refreshments! Join us on Thursdays from 3:15-4:15pm.  
 What are Fireside Chats: 
 
 A space for students to meet, connect, and have a casual conversation about a given topic, or anything else that feels comfortable for everyone else. It can be about the school climate, student life in general, or your favorite show. All students are welcome!

title: SLAM General Body Meeting
description: SLAM General Body Meetings are open to all undergraduate students at  Montclair State University and Bloomfield College  who are interested in getting involved. These meetings are a space for volunteers and members to connect, hear important updates from the Executive Board, and learn about upcoming events and opportunities. General Body Meetings are also a chance for students to share their ideas, contribute to event planning, and build community on campus. Attending regularly helps volunteers stay informed and gain priority for event participation and leadership opportunities throughout the year.

title: Unplugged: Video Game Trivia
description:
Gather your friends and head to 1908 for a night of fast facts, fun questions, and friendly competition at Video Game Trivia Night!  Compete for the chance to win awesome prizes — or just come for some pizza, wings, and maybe a few surprises. 
 How do I sign up? 
 
 Early registration is not required 
 FREE for students with a valid Montclair State ID 
 All students are welcome! 
 
 Where and when? 
 
 Thursday, December 4th 
 7 pm - 9 pm 
 Student Center, 1908 Pizzeria 
 
 Prizes 
 
 1st, 2nd, and 3rd place prizes  for top players tonight! 1st- $20 dining dollars, 2nd- $15 dining dollars, 3rd- $10 dining dollars! 
 Everyone here is also entered for our  weekly door prize , which we’ll give out at the end of the night.  
 
 And don’t forget our  mega raffle at the end of the trivia series  – the more nights you attend, the better your chances of winning something big!

title: Cru Large Group!
description:
Cru is a caring community passionate about connecting people to Jesus Christ!  Join us in learning together on Who Christ is, building a personal relationship with Him, and joining a community filled with love and open arms!  
 This semester we will be focusing on the theme: "The Fruits of the Spirit". We pray that our students will learn about the Fruits of the Spirit in the Bible and be able to bear good fruit in their walk with God.  
 " And they devoted themselves to the apostles' teaching and the fellowship, to the breaking of bread and the prayers.   And awe came upon every soul, and many wonders and signs were being done through the apostles.   And all who believed were together and had all things in common.   And they were selling their possessions and belongings and distributing the proceeds to all, as any had need.   And day by day, attending the temple together and breaking bread in their homes, they received their food with glad and generous hearts,  praising God and having favor with all the people. And the Lord added to their number day by day those who were being saved." - Acts 2:42-47

title: RA+P and Residence Life Coffee House Night
description:
Coffeehouse is our live music event where students can sign up to perform in Russ Lounge. Whether you’re playing, singing, or just coming to hang out, it’s always a great night of creativity and community. 
   
 The goal of the event is to turn Russ Lounge into a performance space that can accommodate an audience, but it’s also a hands-on opportunity to learn how to set up a performance from start to finish. We will be mixing on a Midas M32R, so it's also an opportunity to learn how digital mixers for live audio work. All that prep work culminates in a show featuring Montclair State students from 7 PM to 9:15 PM. We go through the process of setup, performance, and breakdown. IF this interests you, please fill out  this form  for more information on how to join the crew. 
   
 For those interested in performing in the upcoming coffeehouse, we implore you to fill out  this google form , all applicants will receive an email  with the setlist once all responses have been sent out! 
   
 See you soon, stay groovy!! 
   
 All students are welcome, commuters need to be signed in a with a resident following Residence Life guest registration procedures.

title: Friends Day: Be a Buddy
description:
Be a Buddy at Friends Day 2025! 
 Volunteer to be a Buddy on  Sunday, December 7  at the Student Recreation Center from 10am-12pm and/or 2-4pm. As a Buddy, you and another MSU student will be paired with a child or young adult with disabilities to go station-to-station, participate in fun activities and crafts, and help them explore and enjoy the space. You can sign up for  one or both sessions , and  community service hours  will be given. 
   
 Want to volunteer with a friend? Great! Buddies can sign up together as long as you’re both MSU students. This year’s theme is Nickelodeon, so get ready for a fun-filled day inspired by your favorite characters and shows. Come make a meaningful impact while having fun! 
   
 How do I sign-up? 
 
 To register, please fill out  this form .  
 Visit our  Friends Day website  for more information. 
 
 Where and when? 
 
 Sunday, December 7, 2025 
 10am – 12pm and/or 2 – 4pm 
 Student Recreation Center

title: CALI SCHOOL OF MUSIC: Opera Workshop Chamber Opera presents "The Medium"
description:
Montclair State University Opera Workshop Chamber Opera presents The Medium Gian Carlo Menotti, Librettist & Composer 
 Presented with chamber forces, featuring two pianists in place of full orchestra 
 
 Karen Driscoll,  Director William Hobbs & Ginny Stephens,  Pianists & Musical preparation Deborah Caney,  Costume Designer & Coordinator Lucas Pinner,  Scenic Designer Paige Elise Buchanan Stewart,   Livestream Production 
 Alexander Kasser Theater Sunday, December 7 @ 5 PM  Tickets   & 7:30 PM  Tickets   
 Come join us for Gian Carlo Menotti’s hauntingly beautiful opera,  The Medium . 
 A psychological drama filled with mystery, tension, and lyrical intensity,  The Medium   tells the story of Madame Flora, a fraudulent spiritualist whose world unravels when the line between illusion and reality begins to blur. 
 With its gripping music, dramatic characters, and intimate storytelling, this short opera (in an hour) promises to be a powerful theatrical experience you won’t want to miss. 
 SUNG IN ENGLISH 
 Content Advisory:  The Medium contains depictions of séances, alcohol use, psychological distress, the use of a prop firearm and the sound of gunshots.

title: First Gen Drop-In Group
description:
This is a support drop-in group for first generation college students aimed to help ensure that first-gen students are empowered and prepared to reach their full social, professional, and academic potential. Students will have opportunities to build community, empower and support one another through shared experiences with topics that may include, but not limited to, lack of knowledge about college experience/resources, imposter syndrome, financial and family stress, academic struggles and other challenging subject matters. 
 Group Meets: 
 
 First group will be held on September 9, 2025 
 On Tuesdays from 11:30am – 12:30pm in the Health Promotion Drop-In Center 
 
 For more information, contact group leaders Ms. Charisma Jackson, LCSW at  jacksoncha@montclair.edu

title: Weekly Food Recovery Initiative
description:
Join our weekly Food Recovery events, where dedicated volunteers and members gather to make a difference in our community. Each week, participants help collect perfectly good leftover food from Gourmet Dining and transport it to Blanton. There, the food is repackaged into individual microwavable containers and stocked in the food pantry, providing meals for those in need throughout the week.  
 To Participate : RSVP to attend the event each week. Meet in Blanton Hall Residence Hall Kitchenette in the Communal Area (Tell them you are working with Food Recovery), Sign in via Event Pass and your set! 
 Requirements: 
 
 Volunteers must be Food Safe Certified to participate. 
 Complete the certification by following the step-by-step instructions provided in this  link . 
 Once certified, email your certification to  foodrecoverynetwork@sgamsu.org  to confirm your eligibility to participate. 
 
 Your involvement helps reduce food waste and insecurity while supporting individuals in our community who are in need. We look forward to your participation! *Please Note: This event end time is dependent on the amount of food given. You can estimate for max of hour and a half for recoveries.

title: Food Recovery Network General Body Meeting
description:
We’re thrilled to invite you to our General Body Meetings! This is a fantastic opportunity to get involved, meet fellow members, and learn about the exciting plans and initiatives we have in store. 
 - Get to know the team, hear about our mission, and understand the goals and vision for this year. We’ll also introduce key members and roles within the organization. 
 - Learn about upcoming events, projects, and opportunities for involvement. We'll outline our plans and how you can contribute to our success. 
 - Connect with other members, make new friends, and build relationships within our community.  
 - Find out how you can volunteer, join committees, or participate in special projects. We’ll provide information on various roles and how you can make an impact. 
 Whether you’re a new member or a returning one, your presence and participation will help shape the future of our organization.  
 We look forward to meeting you and embarking on this exciting journey together!

title: Weekly Food Recovery Initiative
description:
Join our weekly Food Recovery events, where dedicated volunteers and members gather to make a difference in our community. Each week, participants help collect perfectly good leftover food from Gourmet Dining and transport it to Blanton. There, the food is repackaged into individual microwavable containers and stocked in the food pantry, providing meals for those in need throughout the week.  
 To Participate : RSVP to attend the event each week. Meet in Blanton Hall Residence Hall Kitchenette in the Communal Area (Tell them you are working with Food Recovery), Sign in via Event Pass and your set! 
 Requirements: 
 
 Volunteers must be Food Safe Certified to participate. 
 Complete the certification by following the step-by-step instructions provided in this  link . 
 Once certified, email your certification to  foodrecoverynetwork@sgamsu.org  to confirm your eligibility to participate. 
 
 Your involvement helps reduce food waste and insecurity while supporting individuals in our community who are in need. We look forward to your participation! *Please Note: This event end time is dependent on the amount of food given. You can estimate for max of hour and a half for recoveries.

title: Fireside Chats
description:
Hang out and have casual conversations about anything and everything with other students while enjoying refreshments! Join us on Thursdays from 3:15-4:15pm.  
 What are Fireside Chats: 
 
 A space for students to meet, connect, and have a casual conversation about a given topic, or anything else that feels comfortable for everyone else. It can be about the school climate, student life in general, or your favorite show. All students are welcome!

title: Magnificent Bird / Book of Travelers | Two Song Cycles written and performed by Gabriel Kahane
description:
Experience two distinct works by acclaimed songwriter and performer Gabriel Kahane in one unforgettable day.  
   
 In this duo of intimate solo musical plays, composer Gabriel Kahane blends songwriting and storytelling for a singular, poignant theatrical event. Book of Travelers recounts the strangers he met on a 9,000-mile train journey through a divided America, and Magnificent Bird chronicles a year he spent entirely off-line, and the unexpected turbulence of living quietly. Performed on alternating nights, these two concept albums offer a relentless self-inquiry, and a searing portrait of a world in flux.  To join us, be sure to pick up your free student ticket from the Alexander Kasser Theatre box office or our mobile box office in the student center lobby, Tuesday - Thursday, 11:30 AM to 2:00 PM, and show your student ID at the PEAK desk in the lobby when you arrive for a surprise gift from PEAK. 
   
 Hailed as “one of the finest songwriters of the day” by The New Yorker, Gabriel Kahane is a musician and storyteller whose work spans the theater, club, and concert hall. Highlights of the 2024-25 season include a return to the New York stage in a production at Playwrights Horizons, performances at the Philharmonie de Paris, Wigmore Hall, and the Concertgebouw with fellow composer/performer Caroline Shaw, the premiere of a clarinet concerto for Anthony McGill, a solo debut with the Orchestre National de Lyon, and Kahane’s San Francisco conducting debut in Carla Kihlstedt’s Twenty-six Little Deaths. Kahane's collaborators range from Phoebe Bridgers, Paul Simon, Sufjan Stevens, and Sylvan Esso, to the Danish String Quartet, Roomful of Teeth, and Attacca Quartet. As a writer, he has been published by The New Yorker online and The New York Times; a newsletter and collection of essays on music, literature, and politics can be found at  gabrielkahane.substack.com . 
   
 4:00 pm Magnificent Bird 
 Run Time:  74 minutes, no intermission. 
   
 Magnificent Bird, is an intimate reflection on a year of self-imposed isolation during which the artist set out to write a song every day. With contributions from Andrew Bird, Chris Thile, Amelia Meath (Sylvan Esso), and Pulitzer Prize- winning composer Caroline Shaw, this collection explores the delicate balance between personal introspection and global crises. It’s a vivid musical snapshot of life during a tumultuous period, offering both a personal and universal meditation on modern-day existence. Based on Kahane’s fifth LP. 
   
 7:00 pm - Book of Travelers 
 Run Time:  70 minutes, no intermission 
   
 In Book of Travelers, Gabriel Kahane embarks on a journey across the United States, exploring the intersections of American identity and personal connection through the people he meets along the way. This powerful and emotional piece blends folk, classical, and pop influences to create a nuanced reflection on contemporary life in America. The work is a poignant and intimate exploration of what it means to traverse a country at a crossroads.

title: I AM | Camille A. Brown & Dancers
description:
Five-time Tony nominated choreographer and director Camille A. Brown deepens her explorations of Black joy in Camille A. Brown & Dancers’  I AM . With captivating live and original music,  I AM  launches new queries into the possibilities of imagination—and boldly investigates the future. Inspired by a narrative within HBO’s  Lovecraft Country  and the rhythms of the movie  Drumline , Brown’s 2025 New York Times Critics’ Pick breaks boundaries and “takes her signature interweaving of African diasporic dance forms to new heights.” —  The New York Times 
   
  To join us, be sure to pick up your free student ticket from the Alexander Kasser Theatre box office or our mobile box office in the student center lobby, Tuesdays and Thursdays, 11:30 AM to 2:00 PM, and show your student ID at the PEAK desk in the lobby when you arrive for a surprise gift from PEAK.

title: Rent In Concert | Musical in Concert | Produced by AMP Worldwide
description:
Experience the iconic music of  RENT  like never before. In this sweeping symphonic concert produced by AMP Worldwide, a powerhouse ensemble of vocalists and instrumentalists brings Jonathan Larson’s groundbreaking rock musical to life in a sweeping symphonic concert. Featuring the full score—including “Seasons of Love,” “La Vie Bohème,” and “Take Me or Leave Me”—this electrifying performance celebrates the enduring spirit of love, loss, and chosen family. 
   
 Set in New York City’s East Village at the height of the HIV/AIDS crisis,  RENT  follows a group of young artists as they chase their dreams, navigate heartbreak, and fight to live—and love—fully in the moment. Winner of the Tony Award for Best Musical and the Pulitzer Prize for Drama,  RENT  remains a cultural touchstone with music that resonates across generations. 
   
 To join us, be sure to pick up your free student ticket from the Alexander Kasser Theatre box office or our mobile box office in the student center lobby, Tuesdays and Thursdays, 11:30 AM to 2:00 PM, and show your student ID at the PEAK desk in the lobby when you arrive for a surprise gift from PEAK.

title: Safe Space Training
description:
Our Safe Space Training is an intensive, interactive training that provides attendees with information and tools to combat homophobia, biphobia, transphobia, cissexism and heterosexism, on campus and beyond. Through interactive activities and discussion, participants will personally reflect on their own experiences to enhance their personal and professional development, provide further education, and finally, identify ways to create change on campus and beyond. 
 All sessions are three hours and are first-come, first-served. Pre-registration is required. Registrants are expected to attend the full session. Only individuals who have fully completed the Safe Space Program and have agreed to the expectations of its membership are able to display the sticker/button of our program. Refreshments are not provided; however, you are more than welcome to bring your lunch, coffee, snacks, etc.
